messages.message: Heya, MLH is looking for more ways to serve hackers. We'd love your feedback!

Is anyone interested in learning some technical blogging skills?

I used to write a lot of technical blog posts for Twilio and have done some for MLH. We're looking to publish some cool technical tutorials and breakdowns of hacks you've built for the MLH blog.

If you're interested, comment here! I'd love to share some of the things I've learned and give people a platform to share their work to a wider audience :)

Hi everyone, a freshman girl I mentor asked me if it was okay to wear shorts to her internship this summer, and this has always been something I was unsure about.

I've witnessed male coworkers wearing shorts to work, but I feel like men's shorts are typically longer than women's shorts, and dress codes that may allow men to wear shorts still prevent women from doing so (for example, every school I attended before college). From yall's experiences, is it okay for women to wear shorts to work?

Google engineers in LSH, I need your help!

Last October, I accepted a SWE internship offer with Google, and I have been stuck in host-matching ever since. I've had two host calls (one wasn't interesting to me, the other didn't want me), but a major deterrent for me finding a host is that I had a recruiter quit, got assigned to another recruiter, and had that recruiter quit too. This experience has been so stressful for me, but now I'm taking matters into my own hands.

So if your team (or a team you know) is looking for an intern this summer, please please please contact me. My areas of interest include (but are not limited to) front-end engineering, artificial intelligence/machine learning, and HCI.

I started giving technical talks last year, and ended up speaking at a bunch of conferences. It's been a really great experience and I'd love to see some LSHers give it a try, too. This is mostly targeted at you if you've got ~6+ months of work experience, I'm not sure if it's as immediately useful to current students. But if you're interested in speaking, now or in the future...

1. You should subscribe to https://tinyletter.com/techspeak, which contains calls for speakers (aka google forms where you submit talk ideas), as well as general speaking advice and other good links.

2. Working on a talk submission or trying to brainstorm ideas? Ping me and I'll give you my feedback. I can't promise to respond super-quickly but I'd like to do this for at least a few LSHers. :)

3. Got questions about tech speaking in general? Ask 'em here. I know we have some other members who give tech talks too! (lookin' at Cassidy Williams, for one!)

Hey ladies, I've a small favor to ask of you. We are trying to set up an ACM chapter in my college since the major focus is on competitive programming & next to none on other aspects of CS. We have 3 ACM members plus a faculty sponsor as per the requirements stated here: http://www.acm.org/chapters/students/students/form-gen-interest, but the Indian ACM Council require that the other 5-6 people supporting the chapter should also become members even though it's not stated in the requirements for creating a chapter. The major hurdle is that it's very difficult to convince students in my college to purchase the ACM membership costing about 1000 INR without the chapter even existing as it's not a small sum to pay for any student. So if you guys know anyone who is an ACM member and will be willing to help us bring this chapter to life, I'll be very thankful! Also, any pointers about running ACM chapters are also very welcome. :)

Hi, ladies! Has anyone here battled with or is battling with Imposter Syndrome and/or unconscious bias? Thoughts on the primary reasons which cause it, how to overcome it & not let it become a part of you and your work? 
P.S. - I thought a lot before posting this here because it's a sensitive topic & this is the first time I've ever posted about it on a public forum. I just felt that talking about it with people who are facing it or have faced and overcome something like this can be beneficial to people battling with it. If someone isn't comfortable talking about it on this thread, please feel free to PM me.

http://ww3.haverford.edu/psychology/ddavis/p109g/steinem.menstruate.html
Not related to tech directly, but I thoroughly enjoyed reading it. Thoughts?

https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/debugging-diversity-tech-anita-singh?trk=hp-feed-article-title-channel-add

"I’ve heard stories of recruiters referring to candidates directly as potential “diversity hires.” I can’t be the only one who views this as a damaging label. I don’t want to get a job so I can help a company look good; I’m fine with being a “regular hire,” which I assume would be based on my technical abilities."
"I’ve seen executives of prominent companies openly say that they don’t want to “lower the bar” to hire women and people of color, implying that diversity is synonymous with lowering their standards. *Slow clap*"

Hey LSH, there have been many times when I've started learning something, but I have been completely lost when it comes to implementing something using that freshly gained knowledge. Either I come up with something beyond my reach or something way too basic. I am sure I am not the only person facing this. So I was thinking that since we have people from all backgrounds, employed in a variety of jobs at various levels, can we compile a list of potential projects for various topics/technologies that newbies can take up to learn better, all in one place & put it on GitHub or something. Yay/Nay?
Thoughts, ladies?

As always, we cannot discuss about the gender gap or any other issues without being labelled elitist, sexist, SJW and the like and are forced to retreat to our safe/closed spaces which are the primary reason for all the judgement hurled at us in the first place. For those of you who missed what happened at HH, here is the screenshot of the entire post:
http://imgur.com/d8cCjtX
It just saddens me that people are still so intolerant of measures which are devised to help close the gap and what's worse is that, some people are blind to the problem altogether.

This has been on my mind for quite sometime now. We have a Google Developers Group (GDG) chapter in our college and Women Tech Makers (WTM) is subsidiary of it meant to increase participation of women in technical events/workshops. Last semester, we had a small coding competition and restricted the entry to just girls. About 10 females showed up, which was disappointing as the gender ration in my college isn't that bad, it's decent. 
When I came to college, I used to be the only female in code meets organised weekly. Well, it used to feel a little weird and intimidating having not one other female in the entire room filled by guys coding away at their laptops. Later, to rectify incidents like these my senior and I decided to start a Facebook group for girls who are interested in different areas of CS and help them find the right direction so that they don't feel lost or clueless. I was told that I'm "splitting" groups further and a separate group isn't needed at all as everyone can collaborate and learn. Once, I called out a guy for blatant sexism during recruitment for a club and was called sexist for having formed a girls-only club. What I don't understand is -- why do people harbour such notions? Where do they stem from? 

I've also been told that companies who aim at recruiting females specifically are taking away opportunities from men -- it's not fair to them as the girls just have to compete with the girls while the boys have to compete with everyone. It's basically saying that you're not good enough to compete with the boys, so we'll just put you up against the girls and see who wins. Has anyone had a similar experience? How to tackle these kind of issues as they are incredibly disturbing?

Hi Ladies, I am need of some career advice:

I am wrapping up a contract job at a design agency in Auckland, New Zealand (I'm on a working holiday from the US). I already met with my supervisors and they gave me some very candid feedback on both the positives and negatives. One of the major negatives was that they thought I was not assertive and communicative enough. 

Throughout my 3 months there, I felt like I was constantly chasing people down (clients/teammates) but getting brushed off, which slowed the pace of my turnarounds. I thought it would be enough to politely remind them a few times a day, whether it would through Slack or in person. But it seems like it wasn't cutting it.

Has anyone experienced this? I wonder how I can adjust my communication style moving forward. Maybe it was just something with the team dynamic that didn't mesh well. 

Also, I am debating on taking some time off between the end of the contract and jumping onto the next to reflect on my next steps.

Thoughts?

Wanted to share this opportunity to share your career with NYC high school girls:
The Academy for Software Engineering, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and the NYC Dept. of Education are hosting a women in tech career event for high school students on March 18th, 2015. We’re seeking participants and co-organizers to help put on the event. Details below:

Participant: 
You're interested in either leading a demonstration (hour-long, hands-on learning experience) or a small group discussion (answer questions and lead a discussion about an area of interest to the girls like “10 things I wish I knew before heading to college”, “what it’s like to have a career in tech”, etc.) 

Co-organizer: You're interested in taking more of a leadership role, helping find other successful women to participate, seeking corporate sponsorship, event logistics, etc.
 
We’ve heard from the principal and teachers at AFSE that their students are specifically interested in careers that involve software engineering either directly or indirectly. They’re also interested in careers that have a social impact, like health-tech or education-tech.

Event details:
When: Wednesday March 18th, 2015
Time: 4:00-7:00
Where: AFSE - 40 Irving Place
Who: Up to 100 current high school students

Please contact: Kara@innovatenycschools.org if you’re interested!

Hi LSH - I want to open up a discussion about feeling like a failure. This is a post I made in this group about 8 months ago. I felt really unqualified and having this community to write helpful & encouraging comments and messages made me feel a lot better. 

Women in Tech communities often talk about Imposter Syndrome -- feeling like you don't deserve the successes you've been handed, or that you're not worthy of your accomplishments, or that you are horrible at something that you're actually really good at. The problem is that this conversation leaves out those of us who really ARE behind, learning, or struggling. If the conversation is always about Imposter Syndrome, people who are really lost, confused, or not-yet-qualified get left out of the picture. 

I want to start a discussion about overcoming insecurities and failures. I feel much better now than I did 8 months ago, but I still remember what it felt like for all of those years of being unqualified. 

- Does anyone feel unprepared for an internship or job? 
- Is anyone else struggling with trying to find "their place" in the tech industry? 
- How have you overcome these feelings (if you have)?

----------------------------------- Edit/Addition -----------------------------------
I made this post because I don't think that lack of confidence is always "Imposter Syndrome". I think it's dangerous to ONLY have the "Imposter Syndrome" conversation, because talks about this have an arc like "I thought I was horrible, but then I won 4 hackathons in a row and landed [Amazing Job] at [Amazing Company]! Wow, totes underestimated myself". The problem is that this not relatable for everyone. When we are just starting out, we are not all landing great internships, winning great hackathons, getting amazing grades. For those of us who feel like we don't measure up - and have the rejections to prove it - I wanted to talk about how we can help each other get better & develop confidence to find our place in this industry!!

Hi LSH! Just wanted to recommend another network of Facebook communities that I'm in called Dreamers // Doers! It's a community for "trailblazing women" -- many are Female Founders in their 20s and 30s. I think a lot of LSH members might be interested in this & there are always opportunities posted in Tech and it looks like they could use more of us in there! :) There are a few open groups (Dreamers // Doers: Jobs + Gigs and Dreamers // Doers: Housing plus local groups like Dreamers // Doers: San Francisco and Dreamers // Doers (Lite): New York (only for "regional" posts)) but the REAL value is in the 3 members-only groups. If you're interested in those, sign up through their website here to be put on the waitlist: http://www.dreamersdoers.me/join I work with the founder (Gesche Wai-Yi Haas) so would be able to recommend you if you let me know that you applied! They do charge for membership but I find that it's worth it; totally depends on your financial situation though (may make more sense after graduating college). Hi LSH :) I want to gauge interest for UX Design Crash Course video workshops. 

I've felt that my skills were inferior in the Tech world since I decided I wanted to be the industry about 4-5 years ago, but I'm gradually realizing that I do have skills & abilities that I can share with others, and I really want to give back. I also want to let the younger and less experienced members in LSH know that it's totally okay to be a complete beginner, to be very clueless, and to just be excited about tech even if you don't have the skills yet. Thinking of a product idea and creating an interactive prototype for it is a wonderful way to get started. 

I have a 1-hour UX design workshop that I've run once in-person (hey Joanne Ma) and will be running again in January, but I want to refine it so I can reach more people, pass on my skills, and continue to improve the slide deck and teaching process. 

If you are totally new to design thinking or UX design, and if you've never successfully made a wireframe or interactive prototype before, I would love to walk you through the workshop in a 1-hour video hangout in a small group. Let me know if you're interested by commenting and we'll schedule times after! 

** It is too basic for people with design experience, so you're welcome to join and give me feedback on how I can improve the workshop, but you probably won't learn much! :P

In light of recent news about the Dreamforce panel (basically, Gayle King was chosen as the Interviewer but since she admitted that she knew nothing about tech, all she asked were questions about personal lives & work-life balance, to two very successful technical women -- Susan Wojcicki of Google/YouTube and Jessica Alba of Hollywood/The Honest Company).

Reading about this made me wonder-- should we just stop having "Women in .." panels at all and instead ensure that conferences & panels have as close to 50% women (presenters and attendees) as possible? This is harder to implement but would ensure that people were actually on panels relevant to them and could talk about their jobs, instead of just talking about "lady stuff"-- i.e. Wojcicki could be on a panel with Joseph Gordon Levitt of HitRecord, John Green of VlogBrothers, and the CEO of Vimeo to talk about the future of online video. Jessica Alba could be on a panel with the founders of Beautified, Gwenyth Paltrow of Goop, and Michelle Phan to talk about beauty & lifestyle brands in the digital age. Wouldn't this make a lot more sense and allow the focus of the talks to be about their actual products? Of course this was about Salesforce so those topics might not exactly fit THIS conference-- but then invite people whose professions are relevant to the conference and actually let them talk about their professions.

Another question is-- are we then in a Catch-22 because it will be nearly impossible to ensure that every conference has adequate representation from many different genders, racial & ethic groups, LGBTQ people, etc.? Is it better to have these messy panels than nothing at all?

Hi LSH!! 

This group has totally made my day, every day, for the past month so I thought it's time to start doing the things for tech women I've always wanted to. In Fall 2013, I "founded" a group for college women in tech called The Violet Society. I made it because orgs for older women weren't targeted towards my needs, and those for middle school or other young students were similarly mismatched. Quotes are because we had very few events (all in Summer 2014) and I never put in enough time to grow it. Now that I'm in NYC I am loving the tech community here, and I thought that if I started it up more seriously it could be amazing. 

MVP Components of The Violet Society:
- Weekly hacking meetups focused on a specific tool or product. Hopefully can get one for beginngers "The Lavender Society" :), one for intermediate learners, and one combined (I was thinking Tuesdays--the other Tuesday we would go to NY Tech Meetup and hang out before/after) 
- Female-focused healthy hackathons twice a year (start planning when/if weekly meetups are working)
- Facebook group (already exists) and mailing list (already exists) 

Edited this post because I think I explained it better in my Medium post: 
https://medium.com/the-violet-society/what-young-women-in-tech-really-need-c499eaaf1344
 
Thanks

Hey peeps I'm looking for some job advice. Some of you know me so already know all of this...sorry I keep asking the same thing I'm just really confused. :(  

So i just graduated this spring with a degree in Comp Sci from Tufts. I took 5 years to do it because I decided on it in my 3rd year and kind of struggled through classes because I didn't put as much time into them as i should have. I want to work in web or mobile dev as my career but I was intimidated since we didn't learn that in classes and had to teach ourselves outside of class (I'm not so great at that...I didn't like messy code and hacky solutions because I didn't understand what I was doing or why it worked).

As a result I feel confident about my UX design, HTML, and CSS skills but not so hot on anything like Javascript / Python / Ruby. I'm learning iOS dev this summer at make school but I don't think I'll be good enough for an entry-level iOS dev position (i'm applying to them anyway though). I am looking into iOS internships (if they'll take someone who has already graduated) but also considering going to make school's 2 year program (https://www.makeschool.com/) BUT - then my parents will have to support me financially for another 1-2 years. They're not really ready to do that but they could if I was desperate; on the other hand I want to grow up and have a job already...I just don't want to hate the company I work at. 

Do you know anyone who like pulled an "Intern Queen" (http://www.internqueen.com/content/about-lauren-berger) situation for dev jobs so they could learn on the job and actually get paid? Would that work? Should I just get any full-time job I can find? My ultimate goal is to work at a really world-changing company like Khan Academy but they are also super competitive. I know my skills right now are not even close to where they need to be for that kind of job but I want to get there as soon as I can. 

What will get me there if I really put my all into it? Full-time / multiple internships / Make School / something else? 

Any and all advice is highly appreciated. I tend to get defensive easily so I'll try not to because I really value everyone in this group. <3 And if anyone is in a similar situation to me (don't feel like their degree or experience prepared them for a dev job, not sure what to do now), let me know what you're doing or what you're deciding between.

So this is not SUPER relevant but I was reading this article and one thing bugged me. I couldn't help but get really frustrated at how frequently the author notes the social ties between the founders of this brand and everyone who invests in or helps along their business. Even though they didn't start a tech company, I know that a lot of us are interested in creating products that people love and that drive is there for non-tech consumer brands too. Having an old-world network of privileged individuals clearly helped these co-founders immensely, but many of us don't have that kind of network because of the place we grew up, our race, our gender, socioeconomic status, or other reasons. 

On one hand, I am relieved and excited that because of groups like LSH, we can create our own brain trusts and basically democratize networking, so you don't have to be in any kind of network other than the free & internationally used Facebook to meet smart people.

On the other hand I wonder what those of us who are less-connected can do to develop personal relationships with powerful/influential people who are our potential investors, advisors, etc. if we DON'T have a younger cousin who goes to school with their kid, or don't have uncles who were old college buddies.

Hi LSHers!!! Yesterday I volunteered at Jewelbots' "Take your Daughter to Hack Day" and met this awesome 11-year-old girl named Kika who has already been teaching herself how to code with Codecademy and Khan Academy. She's done HTML, CSS, Javascript, and jQuery and she started PHP & Ruby but some exercises were broken so she couldn't continue (or she got stuck and the hints didn't help). She got to see littleBits for the first time at the hack day and she loved those too! 

Her family lives in Brooklyn, NY but they can't find summer programs for people around her age that actually focus on programming (instead of "look at how fun technology is" topics like 3D printing or Minecraft, or tours of Google and such where you just walk around an *get inspired* instead of learning/building). 

I showed her how to make her own website using Github pages and wrote out a guide so she can replicate the git commands in the Terminal and connected our accounts on Khan Academy so I can coach/mentor her but it was disappointing to see that things like Girls Who Code are only for older girls and other programs were not really teaching much (and they were very expensive-- around $1,000 for one week).

Thought I would ask this group-- do you know any programs or opportunities that would really help her accelerate her learning? I'm in Make School now so I'm going to ask them if she could join next summer as a 12 year old but for this year I need to find something that hasn't started yet that I could recommend!

>> Edit: Made a GoFundMe to buy a littleBits kit for her http://www.gofundme.com/2tc8s8 <<

I honestly have no clue, so I'm reaching out to y'all for your help.

UPDATE: Lovely people, I was able to get sponsorship but I also have a friend, Karen,who is in the same situation that I was in. She is a low-income first generation college student and a woman of color who needs help financing her ticket. She just started her GoFundMe campaign (https://www.gofundme.com/228dp4ta), if y'all could help out, that would be amazing. I love this community and all the support y'all have given me, I hope I can pay it forward and help Karen as well. :)

"Switching to a tech career isn’t easy. In fact, it is really, really hard. It took over two years before I felt a sliver of confidence in myself. It’s like walking into a black hole for the longest time with no light at the end of the tunnel of success or not. The way I look at it, you have to fake it until you make it. You have to try a bunch of things to find those pieces that ignites the passion within you. When I got one step closer solving problems through coding, I could feel the fire burn a little stronger each time." -Brina Lee, Android Engineer, Instagram

"I used to feel like other people were born coders, which is not true. Know that success comes from effort, not natural talent. If you enjoy coding, don't worry about potential. My friend is applying and wanted to connect with someone to ask questions about the application.

Has anyone heard of successful **crowdfunded** conferences / events before?

It seems idealistic but also amazing. A common concern for hackathons I've seen floating around was how much corporate sponsors influence the goals of the event. Though I understand the value they bring, I feel like well intentioned ones would still participate without plastering their names all across that title sponsor banner. It would also lower the barrier to entry for smaller startups who can't afford the inflating sponsor packages.

Concerns: What would you even provide though to individual patrons? If you become a non-profit, I guess you could tap into alumni for tax deduction? 

Just think there should perhaps be a change in sponsorship structuring of the events we've all come to love.

TLDR; Apply
Date: Jan 4-9

I was going to write a medium post, but decided I'd rather just have the text available for you to read on LSH. Square's Code Camp was an incredibly well put together and rewarding experience. The summary is that you are flown out to SF for 5 days (free). 

Honestly, when I first applied, I expected the experience to be a week of drinking the Square Kool-Aid. It wasn't. In fact, they weren't imposing at all. The impression was just immense support. Throughout the week, we attended technical and leadership workshops including topics like Security, Machine Learning, and Imposter Syndrome. At the end of each day, we worked in groups to work on an app. 

I have to say, that this is the moment where I realized how supportive Square was, because some mentors stayed until like 1am to help us. We also visited Twitter and Uber, as well as being introduced to Yelp's women engineers. We also got to meet incredibly leaders like Sarah Friar (Square CFO) and Jack Dorsey (Square CEO).

The support continues because you are added to a Facebook group of Code Camp alumni who I have no doubt would be willing to support me professionally. 

If you don't get in the first time, apply again. I know one of the girls in my class applied at least like 3 times. There are so many ladies among LSH who I had no idea were part of this program. Everyone there is amazing and inspirational. If you have any more questions, comment below.

Hey ladies. So let's talk interviews. Especially if you're going to GHC, start the process NOW.

What companies are you looking at? Would you like an AMA with a company recruiter?

What questions do think is important to ask your recruiter before accepting that internship? Putting together a medium post. Through various experiences, I realized that the interview is a two way street and that you are seeing if that company is a match for you as well. 

A few I thought about:

- What is your full time conversion like? (i.e. I know that for a few companies, you have to re-interview. Which may/may not be a problem. For me, its something to consider as a rising senior and whether I want to deal with that post-graduation. Are you going to be dropped with an exploding offer situation? i.e. accept this offer within 3 days or we don't want you. Which if you encounter this situation... I'll go on a limb and say that you probably shouldn't accept cuz it reflects poorly on the company's recruiting practices.)

- Can you give me an overview of your deployment process? (If its not streamlined, its probably going to be a bit frustrating. Also, I <3 code review.)

- Can you specifically tell me what mentorship is like? For instance, how do you mentor a junior developer to become a senior developer? (This is probably more specific to larger companies. I personally am hunting for a mid - large size company to start out in.)

- How easy is it to switch teams if you are not happy with the project you are on? (This may or may not matter. But it would suck if you had to stick with a team that you were not excited about.)

A lot of these questions also probably apply more/less to full time offers. Let me know what is important to you!

Just a bit of stats on the LSH medium collection + reach. Our reach is pretty impressive.

Total Number of Posts: 32
Number of Posts with 1000+ views: 8

Stats for Top 3 Posts: 
Views, Reads, Read Ratio, Recommends (respectively)
1. 12K, 7.2K, 58%, 230
2. 9.7K, 1.4K, 15%, 202
3. 3.5K, 1.9K, 57%, 128

Total Stats:
- Views: ~ 40,337
- Reads: ~ 19,794
- Recommends: ~ 1,138

I would say that for total stats, they are underestimated since everything that hits 1K get rounded to the lowest hundred.

I believe what they call "reads" is calcuated based on how much time you spend on the article. If they say that its a "5 min read" and you don't spend 5 minutes on the article, then its not counted as read.

What are your favorite tech/tech + startup community publications/sites?

I am not looking for things like Hacker News. That's not a publication edited by a single entity. Also, probably not looking for things like Forbes or TechCrunch (cuz everyone knows about them and they are way too massive / new-ey)

I like things that are either super technical or makes commentary about culture.

She's not a woman in tech... but holy crap this is brave.

"I was branded as a tramp, tart, slut, whore, bimbo, and of course that woman. I was seen by many but actually known by few. And I get it, it was easy to forget that that woman was dimensional. Had a soul, and was once unbroken. When this happened to me 17 years ago, we had no name for it. Now we call it cyber bullying and online harassment."

I like to think that this group supports intersectionality. Thought this was interesting. Reflects many of the things I've been thinking about regarding constantly using more advanced technology as the solution.

Hey! 

*prepares for wall of text*

So in making LSH, I think that it is a great community. It has and still serves it purpose as a launch platform for women and their supporters to be in turn supported and heard in the hackathon community. I have found countless resources and made many friends.

That being said. It has come to my attention that as the community size has grown, even I do not feel comfortable posting certain things. It is an innate problem in any large online community when you do not know who exactly is in the group. This would still be a problem even in an all woman's group of 50 people. This group is now strongly 1450. 

This past month, I started a secret group of 8 people with peers that I trust and know. It has been an awesome ride. Though we are only 8 people, the group is extremely active and the conversation is incredibly engaging. We sometimes talk about tech, feminism, I update them on my life events. Its great. The group probably won't ever grow larger than 10 people. The personal support and guidance it has provided, is immeasurable. The women in the group are from all over the US, and its been pretty awesome.

I strongly, strongly encourage you to try this little social experiment. Spawn your own **secret** groups of peers within this community. Or outside for that matter. Don't let it grow bigger than maybe 10 people. If you need help finding a group, post here, we can all try to help you out. Be personal, talk about non-tech things. Basically, just be friends who happen to have the common interest of hackathons/tech. 

If you see someone looking for a group, and you have space, privately message them and add them. 

Most importantly... HAVE FUN! Muahahahaha.

I really want to talk to a working senior-ish professional about career building. 

(lol, maybe it is too early in the game for me to ask these things but w/e)

My questions:
- Is it wrong for me to have red flags if my salary does not increase each year (this isn't so much about the money as much as an indicator of how I'm doing in the company)
- As a dev, what sort of upward movement is there? junior dev -> project lead -> some random vp title -> cto? 
- When, if ever, should I be changing companies during my career. 
- How can you tell if you're stagnating in your career. If you are, where do you go from there? 
- Granted... only if I'm interested, but what sort of jobs almost definitely require a masters or Phd. Also, how far can most people actually climb up if you only have a bachelor's degree. 

This probably applies more for larger corporate companies like Facebook, Google, Bloomberg, etc. than for startups.

As admin of this group, I wanted to convey a few things to you all about this community and its tone. 

I made this group last year, because I felt like it was important for women to have a voice about how they wanted to approach the gender disparity in hackathons as well as providing valuable feedback to other hackathon leaders included in this group. Like many similar hackathon groups, it is also meant to be a place to share resources, and realize how many awesome people you share a common interest with.

If. At any time. You feel uncomfortable. Or see a post you want removed. Or would like a member removed. REPORT IMMEDIATELY. MESSAGE ME. There is absolute zero tolerance for any inappropriate behavior that makes anyone in this community feel at all uncomfortable.

Ask and you shall receive.

Hey Ladies! 

I hope your summers are going well. Just wanted to post about a co-op opportunity for the fall if you're still looking (recent grads can contact me too). Basically, check out any development job, and they'll probably hire you if you're decent enough. Message me, and I can put you in touch with the recruiter. 

Details:
- http://careers.dattobackup.com/ (keep scrolling down) 
- Housing provided (except you pay 700$/month)
- Norwalk, CT (1 hour train ride from NYC)
- Data backup company

My experience so far:
- learning a lot (for me specifically, object oriented and UML diagrams wheeee)
- they let me do a lot of cool shit
- gave me a lot of free expensive hardware shit 
- the company is about...300-400 people in size? But the development team is super laid back and smaller. Lol...if you come, feel free to poke fun at the pm from the bronx. He's pretty cool. 
- the CEO always takes the time to talk to us and makes sure we still like our jobs lol. (He let us drive his crazy expensive car...? that probably costs at least 2X more than my college education?)

Hey everyone,

I know that everyone in this group probably has this crazy pile of tech shirts/pajama shirts that they're just trying to get rid of. (Or nah...) Anyway, I just stayed at this amazing mental hospital called St. Helena's for bipolar disorder and apparently they can accept shirts with brand names on them (which homeless shelters cannot). Hospitals like these desperately need clothing, so I'm thinking of doing this huge donation haul of tech shirts/any other clothing you don't want any more. Specifically, underwear is something they desperately need. 

Please message/comment if you would like to help with this cause!

Details: 

St. Helena's Hospital Center For Behavioral Health

Address: 
525 Oregon Street
Vallejo, CA 94590

You can just put everything in a box and mail it to them using the address above. I would also include a little note saying how these are donations (from ______). For those of you on the east coast, I *highly* recommend contacting mental hospitals in the area so you won't have to pay expensive shipping. 

Also, I plan on writing an iOS app revolving around mental health (WebMD for disorders, pill notifications, disorder information, treatment options, hospital ratings, etc). Let me know if you would like to help!

In case you missed SXSW this year, this comes from an AWESOME person who needs more applicants from communities like Ladies Storm Hackathons.  [White-hat] Hack the government. Do it. Make it better, please. 

** Mention in your online application that I referred you as a member of Ladies Storm Hackathons/Hackathon Hackers. **
----------
"Why We Need You in Government

Posted by Mikey Dickerson 

Editor’s Note: Mikey Dickerson, Administrator of the U.S. Digital Service, and Jen Pahlka, former Deputy CTO of the United States and founder of Code for America, gave a talk at the 2015 SXSW Music, Film + Interactive Festival on “How Government Fails and How You Can Fix It.”  For those who weren’t there, here’s Mikey’s opening remarks:

This all started for me in October 2013.  Healthcare.gov had just launched, and if you remember, it wasn't going too great.  I was minding my own business in California working for Google.  Although I had volunteered for the Obama campaigns, I had no other connection to the Administration and no government experience at all.

I was visiting some friends from the campaign in Chicago when through some complicated series of connections that I still don't understand, I heard that the White House was looking to organize some kind of assessment of the website, and was asked to call in to a phone conference where I would get more information.  The phone call was at 8:30 Eastern, so 5:30AM for me, so I was not too happy but I did it anyway.  On the phone was a guy named Todd Park.  I had never met Todd; I looked him up on Wikipedia while on the phone.  With a couple more phone calls, I was talked into flying to Washington, D.C. for a few days to evaluate the situation.

Here was the situation when I got there: The government shutdown was over, and the failure of Healthcare.gov was the lead story on cable news all day every day.  The original estimate from the Congressional Budget Office had been that 7 million people would enroll in this first enrollment period, but Todd said that given the circumstances if we could manage 4 million, that would be a home run.  He said they needed an independent outside team to figure out how bad the problems were and if they could be fixed to save the site this year. Also that if it couldn't be fixed, then it would be a catastrophe for the policy, with the 2014 election coming and the unpopular law having failed to launch.  Democrat support would probably fracture, the election would be a disaster, the President would be a lame duck two years early, and nobody would try again for a generation.  But you know, we want your honest assessment.

We looked around and found some really surprising things.  One was that there was no monitoring of the production system.  For those of you that run large distributed systems, you will understand that this is as if you are driving a bus with the windshield covered.  Second was that there were hundreds of people and dozens of companies involved, but nobody in charge.  Third was that there was no particular urgency about the situation.   As I would come to understand, nobody was acting like there was anything out of the ordinary because there was nothing out of the ordinary.  The whole system had worked as normal and produced the expected result, which was a web site that was overpriced by hundreds of millions of dollars and did not work, at all.

Since there were so many really basic problems, we ended up recommending that the site could probably be fixed to work well enough to enroll the 4 million people.  Of course, we were then asked to stay to follow through and implement those recommendations.  (This is called commitment escalation, and we will do it to you.  This is the only time I will warn you.)  I ended up going home in January—my 3 day trip had turned into nearly 3 month stint.  I submitted an invoice for the nine week period ending December 31, 2013, and the mean hours per day worked was 17.5.  I was hallucinating and having other problems from not having slept enough for three months.  This was the hardest thing I have ever done and I hope nothing ever comes close to it again.

When I went home, other people had taken over the day to day operations and helped finish the enrollment period, which went to March 31.  But things did not go back to normal for me; they only continued to get weirder.  There had already been media interest in the people from the "tech surge," and in March the final enrollment number of over 8 million was announced, and three of us from the “tech surge” team were on the cover of Time Magazine.  In May I went back one more time for an event where we met the President.

I tell you all this not to prove how amazing we were, but exactly the opposite.  Nothing we did was technically difficult by any standard we are used to.  There were simple problems with simple solutions.  The solution to the lack of monitoring was to install monitoring.  The solution to nobody being in charge was to make everybody come to the same room where we could coordinate.  And so on.  It was not a hard engineering problem, and any of you could have done it, and it was also more important and meaningful than anything I could have accomplished in a lifetime working at my old job.  Beyond the 8 million people that got access to health care for the first time, which for many of them was a matter of life or death, I don't think we are ever going back to the time when people who actually need health insurance are not allowed to buy it.

So I went back to my old job and tried to care about it.  I was not successful.  On one hand the company does not need me; there are thousands of other engineers that are as good or better.  On the other hand, if I succeeded beyond anybody's wildest dreams the net effect is that some extra billions of dollars would go to one billionaire instead of a different billionaire.  It was hard to see why I should bother, and still is.

But meanwhile, there were wheels turning in Washington, D.C., where people that had been working on government technology reform for years had received a huge boost from the Healthcare.gov meltdown.  So pretty soon Todd Park was calling me again, asking me to come work for a group that has now become known as the U.S. Digital Service.  It took a few months to convince me, but in August I finally left Google forever and moved to Washington.

The basic theory of the U.S. Digital Service was to replicate the ingredients that were successful on turning around Healthcare.gov, for a few other high priority projects.  With the money we basically had left over in an IT oversight fund, I expected to hire about 10 to 12 people and take on three projects, which I thought would be the Affordable Care Act, the VA, and immigration.  I expected that the difficult problems would be recruiting 10 more engineers to make this questionable life decision, and getting agencies to accept outside help.

Since then several unexpected things have happened.  Where I was worried about recruiting 10 people, I actually got over a thousand applications.  The demand from the agencies is also more than we could ever satisfy.  We have met with 22 of them and identified around 60 projects that need attention.  And possibly the most surprising thing was that Congress passed an omnibus spending bill in December, and it included the full $20M funding request to operate the U.S. Digital Service.  This will allow us to grow to about 40 people and take on 10 projects in 2015.

And this is the part where you come in.  Right now, at least, in this moment, we have overwhelming demand for engineers like yourself in the federal government.  And we have overwhelming supply of people that want to come help.  For these reasons, we have proposed in the President's 2016 budget a total of $105 million to create copies of the U.S. Digital Serivce team inside all of the 24 major agencies, for a total of around 500 people.  The artificial barrier that has kept the technology industry and the public sector separated on different evolutionary paths is porous right now, and if enough people cross over, it can be destroyed.

Some of you, not all of you, are working right now on another app for people to share pictures of food or a social network for dogs.  I am here to tell you that your country has a better use for your talents.  The Affordable Care Act, I just told you about.  The Social Security Administration mails checks from a mainframe running COBOL, which might kind of be OK except that more than half of the workforce that maintains it is at or near retirement age.  What happens then?  The Department of Veterans Affairs has a serious backlog of disability claims.  The U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Service processes permanent resident applications and everything else on paper.  If you lose your green card, it will take you 6-8 months to get a new one and in the meantime you will not be able to prove you have the right to be in the country or get a job.   All of these are information processing problems and all of these are matters of life or death to millions of citizens and all of them are things you can fix if you choose to.

So that's what it all boils down to.  This is a market economy and you—and your talents—are the crucial capital. Whether you know it or not, you are making decisions about how we allocate resources.  We can solve any of these problems but we have to choose to do it.  The most sobering thing about my time in government is to really understand on an emotional level that this country belongs to you and me and it is exactly as good as we make it.  Grownups are not going to fix it for us and billionaires are not going to fix it for us.  We either do it ourselves, or nobody does.  I will take questions.

Ready to get involved?  Apply here: www.WhiteHouse.gov/us-digital-service.  "

Many of my feminist friends not in tech dislike being called "girls" because they consider it belittling, infantilizing, and dismissive. In tech, though, I've noticed a lot of women-centric organizations with "girls" in their name - Girl Geek Dinners, Rails Girls, Django Girls, Girls in Tech, etc - many of which are started and/or run by women, and inclusive of both adults and teenagers. I also don't read much about criticism of "girls" as opposed to "women" in tech essays. As I am not female-bodied, I'd love to hear from y'all how you feel about being called "girls in tech." Do you identify with that? Would you prefer "women" or "ladies" instead? Do you consider this an academic issue? I'm interested in hearing whatever you have to say about this!

I had this in my notes for a while. I know it's not enough just to talk about, but I think it's a start. I wanted to highlight the situation around first.
Relevant to post it here too !

During his keynote for Interaction15, distributing 5 copies of his book “You’re my favorite client”, Mike Monteiro, stopped after the first one: “Okay, no more guys.” He gives the rest to 4 girls close to the stage: “They make 70 cents to your dollar, (and back to the boys, about the book) you can afford it”.

I think it's an amazing way of focusing the attention on the problem. I wrote a few lines on it (one of the most amazing keynotes I've ever seen btw) to gather attention. I think by exposing the problem at the end and keeping it short makes the reader think, lets an impression, and hopefully makes it engage discussion. 

I think the more we talk about it, the more barriers we'll break.

College students majoring in CS or an engineering discipline and technical professionals

Hi everyone! I run ProjectCSGIRLS (www.projectcsgirls.com), a national youth-driven nonprofit working to close the tech gender gap through running a national computer science competition for middle school girls and workshops around the country. Our competition challenges girls to be makers and use tech to develop projects with social impact. This year, we reached over 800 girls nationally through our competition and regional workshops and this coming year (2015-2016) will be our third year running the program. We've partnered with several national women in tech organizations and have received corporate sponsorship and national press coverage for our work. 

Applications are now open to all interested high school and undergraduate students to join the 2015-2016 ProjectCSGIRLS team so if you’re interested, please fill out the form below by July 30th 11:59 PM EST. All details regarding team member responsibilities are in the form. Let me know if you have any questions!

I have a serious question about work-life balance. I'm in the process of finalizing a decision for full-time work and I would like to know how tied to your life is your job? I just finished a pretty awesome semester abroad, except for one course. Algorithms is very important for us majors who want jobs and I basically failed it. I don't know if it was our teacher or just me being me (not the first class I've failed), but in general, I want to ask how people have dealt with their feelings of inadequacy in the classroom. Feeling like you're hopeless, you can't possibly do as well as the other people in your class, all the opportunities you've gotten were flukes somehow. I'm basically quoting my inner monologues right now. I dunno, it's a destructive thing, and I'm about to be a senior and if I can learn to help myself deal with these feelings productively, I'd like to do it sooner rather than later.

Also, because Algs is so important, what are texts/videos/courses that you guys might have used to learn them well? This summer I was going to read through a text book and teach myself. I'm armed with enough background knowledge and general knowledge that I won't be starting from square one, but anyone has any advice for that, it would be great!

(also I hope this post isn't too off topic; I didn't really know where else I could ask such questions.)

Hi LSH, recently I was thinking about how companies tend to recruit from the same top schools and those people become interns who become full time etc. If those schools aren't very diverse, the cycle is going to keep repeating itself and everyone will continue wondering where all the women and other minorities are.  So, I'm looking to you to help me crowd source university cs diversity data.  I'm very interested in feedback on how this could be improved, some initial notes are the I'm focusing on gender and race (and leaving out some other important categories) because I don't actually think the other data exists, but if it does-- please prove me wrong!  Also, I am absolutely aware that gender is not a binary, but again I worry that the remaining data doesn't exist. However I'd be thrilled to be wrong, so add what you know.

GRACE HOPPER TIPS. 

Hey Ladies, 
Last year I had the honor of going to GHC thanks to a scholarship from Microsoft for its lady interns. I figured I'd give you guys some protips so you go in less noobie than me!  

1.) Make sure you submit your resume @ GHC's resume drop:
http://gracehopper.anitaborg.org/resume-database/

Why should you do this? 
Firstly, lots of companies go through their database to interview candidates, generally at the conference itself. I, noobishly, did not do this. 
Secondly, lots of companies have dinners where they have girls come in to talk to developer/reps from the company. (Pinterest and DropBox to name a few from last year) 

2.) Make sure you go to the tech fair, earlier the better. Some companies give out interviews at the job fair. 

3) If GHC has the talk on Office Politics, I recommend it! I think last year it was by Jo Miller( googled it: http://gracehopper.anitaborg.org/ghc-community-blog/ghc14/ghc14-winning-at-the-game-of-office-politics-part-2/ so I'm not positive but thats what this implies ).  It gives you some protips on how to view the work place and the small things that may go unnoticed if it wasn't brought to your attention.

4) I saw some people asking how to dress. 
---> wear what you want, texas is going to be hot! 
---> jeans and t-shirt is fine 
---> if you're like me and you're like, uhh that feels a little awkward for me, then cardigan/blazer/jean jacket if you want with dress/jeans/leggings with flats/sandals is totally fine. 
--> Really. I swear. Id stay away from sweatpants though! 

5) to my earlier point about the dinners companies hold, when at the tech fair, i'd just ask if they have one and if you can go. Some people told me about theirs, others, I found out later, were open and I missed an opportunity. 

6) Network. You're going to be around a lot of leading ladies, so be bold! Everyone from a company will probably be wearing their shirt, so go ahead and ask away! I wish I had asked more :P 

GOOD LUCK AND HAVE FUN :)

Hey friends!

This is a job posting.

TL;DR: Be my dev evangelism intern!!! :D

Title: Venmo Developer Evangelism Intern

Things you may do:
- Create technical content for our blog (and various other channels) to show developers how to work with the Venmo API or to use new technologies.
- Speak and share your expertise at meetups, local events, conferences, and hackathons.
- Give tech talks, workshops, and lunch 'n' learns in and outside the office. 
- Build open source projects and demos with the Venmo API.
- Network with individual developers and organizations.
- Gathering and socializing product feedback that will inform engineering, sales, and marketing decision making.
- Support our developers wherever they are.
- Put together some projects with Venmo dev evangelists for increased engagement (and fun, of course).
- Volunteer for local technical organizations.

Skills/Experience that would help:
- Experience working on open source projects.
- Experience at a prior technical internship.
- Experience managing social media accounts.
- Leadership and service in developer communities.
- Strong technical writing skills demonstrated via blog posts and other written work.
- Strong and diverse engineering skills: being a generalist is a Good Thing™.
- Social skills: you're willing to put yourself out there and reach out to those with whom you might not normally interact.
- Public speaking experience.
- Friendly and approachable people do well as the teachers and mentors we're looking for.
- Ability to work irregular hours and some weekends to support hackathons, conferences, user groups, and other developer events.
- Ability to stay professional as you promote the Venmo brand and interact with a variety of different people and groups.
- Having a network in NYC would help (but isn't necessary).
- Be a team player, but also be willing to work on your own sometimes.

Super intense requirements:
- Be a Venmo user.
- Be at least 18 years old.
- Be a Whitney Houston fan.

Benefits of the gig:
- You'll have a HUGE network in NYC after your summer with us.
- You'll get to chow down on the food and check out our awesome weekly yoga classes in the office.
- You'll get to work with really, really cool people.  
- Your public speaking and writing skills will explode with greatness.  Or at the very least, they'll be exercised.
- You'll actually get paid to mess with code, write pretty much anything you want, go to events, and be social.  If that doesn't sound like fun, I don't know what does.
- You'll have the freedom to work on what you want, but the structure and guidance of an professional dev evangelist (lol that's me).  Plus some engineering and marketing folks.  They're cool too.

How to apply:
Fill out this super high-tech form.
http://reductress.com/post/tech-now-hottest-industry-for-women-to-be-shut-out-of/

Call for Papers

Workshop on Testing and Quality Assurance and Services for Big Data and Application Systems

In conjunction with

The 28th International Conference on Software Engineering and Knowledge Engineering (SEKE2016)

Hotel Sofitel, Redwood City, San Francisco Bay, California, USA
July 1 - July 3, 2016

This workshop wants to provide an international platform for academic researchers and practitioners to exchange and discuss the emerging issues, challenges, needs, and solutions on Big Data quality assurance and QoS of big data application systems. Original and research articles are solicited in all aspects including theoretical studies, tools, standards, practical applications, industry experience and experimental prototypes.

All submitted papers will be peer-reviewed and selected on the basis of both their quality and their relevance to the theme of this special issue. Potential topics include, but are not limited to:

Big Data quality assurance standards
Big Data quality control processes and systems
Big Data quality assurance management
Big Data quality validation and automatic tools
Big Data system quality validation methods
QoS for Big data system infrastructures and platforms
Automatic validation methods and tools
QoS quality modeling and study
Big Data QoS parameter validation and evaluation
Knowledge-based for big data quality validation
Quality monitor and visualization
Big data quality services and systems
Big Data application system quality assurance management

Papers must be written in English. An electronic version (Postscript, pdf, or MS Word format) of the full paper should be submitted using the following URL: https://www.easychair.org/conferences/?conf=seke2016 (submission website will be open after January 1, 2016). Please use Internet Explorer as the browser. Manuscript must include a 200-word abstract and no more than 6 pages of 2-column formatted Manuscript for Conference Proceedings (include figures and references but exclude copyright form).
Publication:

All of accepted papers will be included the proceeding of SEKE2016, and must be presented in the workshop as a part of the SEKE2016 conference program. Some best ranked papers from this workshop will be selected for a super-sized special issue of the International Journal of Software Engineering and Knowledge Engineering (IJSEKE) to be published in December 2016 for early dissemination.

Paper submission due: Midnight EST, March 1, 2016

Notification of acceptance: April 20, 2016

Early registration deadline: May 10, 2016

Camera-ready copy: May 10, 2016

 
PC Chair:

Jerry Gao, San Jose State University, USA
PC Co-Chairs:

Greogory Kapfhammer, Allegheny College, USA 

Oum-El-Kheir Aktouf, Grenoble INP, France

For inquiries, please contact jerry.gao@jerry.gao

Hello ladies (and gentlemen)! I'd really love your advice about doing an internship this summer with a large corporate company versus a small start up. 

Over the past couple of summers, I've interned with large corporate companies, only somewhat meaningful to me, but the pay and benefits are incredible. This year I decided to widen my scope and apply to more start ups that I believe in, and I've been offered a position on a team of 12 for a VR startup that is doing pretty well. Not only would I be working in a field I care about, I would also be doing a huge array of things and learning a lot. But to some extent I am concerned about pay. Housing will be covered ($600-$800), and they will roughly double that for all other costs.  

I also have another offer from a huge company with a big name, awesome benefits, and free housing. Has anyone else been in a similar situation, or have any advice? Thanks in advance!

Last reminder: presentation on Intro to Xamarin in 10 minutes -- click the online meeting link to join this live session!

Interested in learning about Xamarin? Please join us tonight at 7 PM CT for an introduction! We'll be going over the basics, and do a few demos -- and it's all online tonight!

https://meet.lync.com/stdntpartners/katie.anderson/UFHNU471

Also, it is in recommended that you do a few things if you wish to follow along or get started doing mobile development with Xamarin.:

1. You need to create your Xamarin account and get your Student License. Go to https://www.xamarin.com/student and follow the on screen instructions. If you already have a dream spark account, you can get started though that, however some students have reported that they get asked for a credit card before completing their sign up. You do not/should not need to enter a credit card to get access to your student license. IF you get asked this, there is another route that you can go. Below the big "Take me to Microsoft Dream Spark to get started" button, there is a link that is labeled "Apply for Xamarin for Students". This will ask a few basic things like name, Student Email Address, where you are going to school, what country you are in, and a phone number to be reached at. This process takes a few weeks to get your account, but it means no credit card is needed. please try the Dream Spark route first before doing this method due to the short time before the talk.

2. Once you have your account, you will need to set up your environment. Xamarin for Students comes with visual studio integration. however it also has its own stand alone Xamarin Studio which will let you do the exact same things. No matter which path you choose you will need to get your environment installed with the latest mobile SDK's. The installer should do this for you and will walk you though it. If you are stuck or need help, you can look at https://developer.xamarin.com/guides/cross-platform/getting_started/ which tells you how to get your environment set up. If that does not work, you can reach out to the Midwest's Xamarin MVP at mitchmuenster@gmail.com and he can help you trouble shoot your installation. 

3. Finally, you will need to get your phone set up to develop with. 

Android
Go to Android Settings / Settings > About Phone 
Repeatedly tap on the section that is titled "build number" until you see a message saying "congrats you are now a developer"

iOS: INPORTANT: you can only develop for iOS if you have a apple desktop or laptop running a non hacked install of OSX. This is an apple mandated thing, you cannot get around it.
First you will have to create your development account. To get started, go to https://developer.apple.com/programs/ and click the blue "enroll" button at the top right hand corner.
Pay the $99 USD to activate your apple developer account. There is no "free" apple developer program for students
Create Provisioning profiles for your accounts for your dev, and production envroments.
Register your apple phone or tablet to your developer account, with out doing this you cannot push your app to a iOS device you own.

Windows
If you have a dreamspark account you are already most of the way to getting your self set up as a windows phone devloper. to get started follow the guide here https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/alicerp/2013/05/10/students-how-to-set-up-your-free-windows-phone-dev-account-with-dreamspark/

On 11/07 - 11/08 we're excited to be a melting pot of incredible talent, hardware, and mentors to explore the intersection of social good and technology. People have had a lot of fun at our past hackathons and we hope you can be part of it too!

This year, we are continuing on our main 4 impact areas of Education, Inequality, Health & Wellness and Energy & Environment. In addition, this year, across all themes, we looking to focus our efforts on 3 areas: 
1. Deconstructing the issue - What tools and visualizations can we create to help people understand our impact areas better? 
2. Providing better access - Many do not have the privilege to have access to education, health or energy. How can we build tools to increase their accessibility? 
3. Challenging the status quo - Let us rethink the current solutions to our impact areas. Can we create better tools for the future?

hi everyone! i found this course on MIT OCW about UI design http://ocw.mit.edu/courses/electrical-engineering-and-computer-science/6-831-user-interface-design-and-implementation-spring-2011/

I'm thinking of putting together a 'pseudo- UI/UX degree' by compiling online courses and resources on a git hub read-me so anyone can access it. If anyone is interested let me know!!!

Although the Rails community runs this program, it is language agnostic and this year, for the first time, there's a Lua project among the list of choices, which I'm responsible for.
Sailor, a web framework in Lua, is the project I'll be mentoring: 
https://teams.railsgirlssummerofcode.org/projects/109-sailor-a-web-framework-in-lua

I've devised some tasks suitable to beginners and intermediary programmers, but projects can be discussed. You don't need to already be familiar with the Lua programming language. If you'd like to participate on it or know anyone who would like, please contact me! 

If you are interested in other projects, there are many others here: https://teams.railsgirlssummerofcode.org/projects

Cheers!

For International Women’s Day I set out to evaluate the representation of women and other minorities on companies’ websites. How can we see ourselves as leaders if they show no one like us that have succeeded? I am calling it the #ICanSeeMe project. 
Because no tools existed to measure a website's diversity, I made one up. I am starting to write up the diversity reports, and here is the first one.  If you only read one part, check out the minorities in power section. https://medium.com/i-can-see-me/diversity-at-apple-8f6f829caa25#.ar5lgljkk 

I have reports for IBM, Amazon, HackerRank, Twitter, DropBox, Brit+Co, Pinterest, and Palantir in the works, but comment if there is another site you would especially like to have evaluated. Also are there any measures of diversity you feel were left out?

The other week I received one of those generic emails about Visual Studio, and I noticed that out of the 11 clip art people only 2 were girls. And both were in the background or off to the side (see pic). So I decided to check out the VS website and noticed the trend continued. Men outnumbered women on every part of the website with 2 or more people with the sole exception of continuous integration (ps props to who ever designed that page). In fact, most of the time they doubled to quadrupled the number of women. And although there were numerous examples of code commits, only 2 of those were by women. I think that recent GitHub study suggests that number should be way higher. 
And its not just a gender issue. Of the 107 people I counted (35 females and 72 men), not a single one had a visible disability. These problems have easy fixes. There could be clip art people in wheel chairs (there is already one on a yoga ball), or with hearing aids, or canes. Or for a start one of the men on the Visual Studio Purchasing Options - Enterprise could be a woman. So I started one of those idea submission things, and if it gets enough votes Microsoft's Visual Studio team will review it. So please vote for this issue: 
https://visualstudio.uservoice.com/forums/121579-visual-studio-2015/suggestions/12552543-make-visual-studios-website-ux-and-advertising-mor 
I know its just clip art, but they represent what programmers look like and larger systemic issues in engineering. #ILookLikeAnEngineer would not have caught on if it were unnecessary. Women and disabled people already receive many subliminal messages that they don't belong in engineering, the last thing they need is their preferred IDE's website subconsciously saying it too.

Hi y'all! I'm working with Osmos Academy and we're in the middle of a campaign to bring virtual reality to children in the hospital!

Super excited right now because we're going to be featured on CTV and CBC for the work that we're doing and have done.

One thing we noticed is that VR games do not currently take into account a lot of accessibility needs (e.g. limited mobility in hands/arms, limited neck/head movement, etc.) so after having met with kids with a lot of varying abilities, parents, medical professionals, game designers and developers, we are making a game for the kids in the hospital.

We're in full swing now, and thought I would post a link to our github here (we're making it completely free/opensource because +1 accessibility and affordability!) and also don't want to limit people who can contribute by location (we're based in Montreal). https://github.com/osmosacademy/vr-campaign

If you have any questions, I'm happy to answer :) 

Cheers!

Warning: interview rant.

So today, I fucked up 1 of my 5 interviews for a particular company. Normally I wouldn't be too fazed, but the interviewer was so rude about it that I felt incredibly pissed off at the end.

During the interview, the guy told me that he wasn't there to give me hints or nudge me in the right direction when I was stuck. I personally think it's absolutely ridiculous to expect a candidate to go through a relatively complex system design question without any help, especially in a pressured setting like this.

The second thing that really pissed me off about this interviewer was his attitude. Normally, I like to illustrate my algorithms before I code to make sure I really understand how to solve the problem. Time was running short, and I was still trying to work out the problem in pictures, and the interviewer literally told me that he "just wanted to see code on the board."  

Not gonna lie, I didn't have an impressive amount of code to show at the end, but seriously, how does he expect for me to "get code on the board" when I'm stuck on how to solve the problem fundamentally because he won't give me any damn hints?

I'm so bitter about this. I'm thinking about emailing my recruiter, but I honestly don't think it'll make a difference on whether I'll get an offer.

Does anyone have advice on what I should do?

@ everyone, but especially hackathon organizers: 

I keep getting invited to hackathons I've applied to with only about 2 weeks (or less!) notice until the event. By that point I'm almost never able to go (even though I'd love to) because I have to ask off for work more than 2 weeks in advance (standard for most places, I'm sure)... and I'm usually already scheduled to work for that weekend. 

Question(s): Is this becoming the norm? Or have I just been unlucky recently with the hackathons I'm applying to? I don't recall ever having this problem before but it's happened a few times this semester so I'm pretty bummed. Preemptively asking off for work isn't an option since I need those hours if I'm available... like if I don't get accepted to the hackathon.

For hackathon organizers in this group... pls pls pls consider working to push out acceptances and info on travel accommodations (if any) at least 3 weeks in advance for us poor folks having to work our way through college?

Does anyone else feel like while you might be comfortable going to class, doing class projects, student orgs in school, etc., you feel very out of your depth and intimidated in other computer science or developer related communities? I'm talking hackathons, going to developer meetups, even research. If I'm at a hackathon, I feel naturally a lot more withdrawn or tense and I don't feel as if I can feel comfortable striking up conversations or making connections with other hackers, therefore limiting the experience that I get out of it, which is really disappointing because these side communities outside of school are equally as important to SOME people as actually going to school and getting a degree in terms of opportunities and networking and connections.

Like it's not even like a lot of these communities have overt bro-grammer natures, its just genuinely uncomfortable. I just feel like guys have a very easy rapport with each other in these communities while women are kind of on the outside looking in unsure how to tap into the conversation.

Random thought but for me the time when I realize the uneven ratio in tech the most is when I go to the women's bathroom in our CS building on the busiest floor in the middle of the school week and the toilet seats are still up from someone cleaning them the night before and its like 2 pm and I'm like lol #AwkBathroomRealizations

NCWIT Collegiate Awards

Applications for the NCWIT Collegiate Award are now open! The NCWIT Collegiate Award honors outstanding undergraduate women for their computing and technical accomplishments. Apply today!

Awardees receive:

·   $7,500 cash award
·   A trip to the award ceremony at the annual NCWIT Summit in Hilton Head, South Carolina
Applications for the award close on February 15, 2015. Applicants must be a member of the NCWIT Aspirations in Computing Community, a junior or senior in college, and a computing major.

Apply now to become a member of the NCWIT Aspirations in Computing Community!

The NCWIT Aspirations in Computing Community provides program participants with resources, connections to peers, corporate and university partners, visibility, presentation and speaking opportunities, and much more. We’re connecting technical female students to a large group of peers and over 575 corporate, non-profit, and academic partners to build a strong network of women in computing.

Technical women in college are invited to apply to become part of the NCWIT Aspirations in Computing Community. Apply online to become a member of the NCWIT Aspirations in Computing Community today! All female college students majoring in computing are welcome and encouraged to apply.

Benefits of the NCWIT AiC Community:
·   Receive exclusive access to internships from top technology companies
·   Connect with other technical women across the country, and start building a professional network
·   Apply for the NCWIT Collegiate Award
If you know of a college student that you think should join the Aspirations in Computing Community or who should apply for the NCWIT Collegiate Award, encourage them to apply! If you have any questions about the NCWIT Aspirations in Computing Community or the NCWIT Collegiate Award contact us as aiccommunity@ncwit.org.

With all of the amazing applications we'll be receiving we need help reviewing them! If you have already graduated college with a technical degree and are interested in helping to review applications please complete this form. The application review period will be from February 16-March 15, 2015.

As someone who grew up very economically disadvantaged and did not do well in school when I was younger, it's very hard to find role models with similar backgrounds. Normally, the greats are typically somewhat well-to-do white dudes who always excelled in math. Anyhow, for anyone who grew up in a similar boat, I found a very cool example of someone who went on to do great things from a similar background  (Founder of company who created OpenGL, WebMD, James Clark) I don't necessarily want to be exactly like him, but it's a great reminder that you don't have to be the expected outcome of your environment. 

http://www.biography.com/people/james-clark-9542204#early-life
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_H._Clark

Question about running a Women in Tech group:

So for the past two years I have been trying to run a women in technology group at my school. The problem is I have NO idea how to organize anything. We have been able to finagle fundraisers and activities for our women in tech at my university and have had passionate enough few key members who have helped to really drive our projects and workshops, but it's been extremely hard. Most of our members are electronic engineering students.  As a Computer Science major with a concentration in SE, I've been doing my best to learn about electronic engineering so we can work on projects, but making sure that we offer things like interview prep or workshops has been really hard to make sure I can offer the right resources to the right people.I also want to be able to encourage our graphic design majors to join (SERIOUSLY! They are so important and I always want to help them when they say their front end courses are killing them)

Ultimately, I would love to have a well functioning machine of women in tech including electronic engineering, computer science, and graphic design majors and also girls just simply interested! The goal would be something like the amazing Tech@NYU (http://techatnyu.org/) I was lucky enough to link off to their page from Terri Burns amazing project on "The Periodical".

So my questions are

- What has been the most effective hierarchical design for ladies that run Women in Tech oriented groups? I want to make sure that members feel ownership of the group, but at the same time, I want to also make sure that it is clear who to refer to on specific issue.

- What have you done to effectively encourage participation in your groups?

- This seems like a very specific question, but has anyone had any kind of way of organizing a social media plan? I think this is very important and something I am horrible at. It's also hard to find the time to when I've had a lot of difficulty delegating responsibilities and been doing a lot of the organization and setting up of events and connections. 

- What kinds of workshops or events have you used in your groups that you felt went over well? How did you go about setting them up?

- How do I set up mock interviews with technical companies and make sure I get enough resources for the women in electronic engineering? I am also afraid that our curriculum is extremely outdated. I don't want our girls to get extremely discourages if they are very unprepared for technical interviews.

- How do you gather funding? A lot of the time we want to put on events but do not have the funding. We don't get anything from out CS or Engineering departments, so we'd have to figure out good old fashioned fundraising or have sponsors, which I'm really not sure how to set up. We've done a lot of food related sales, but I'm not sure how effective that is. We have a little over $100 and most of our money goes toward projects. Honestly, I've spent a lot of my own money making sure we have the right resources. (Wires/electronic components for project/Snacks/etc)

I know this is a serious TL;DR, but I would appreciate ANY suggestions.

For fulltime LSH-ers:
Do any of you attend (technical) conferences? I work in storage and networking, and there are a lot of conferences that happen in these fields in the bay area and around the US. I feel weird asking my boss to fund me to attend these events (and skip days of work), especially if they don't end up adding significantly to my technical understanding.

Also, in general I find it more difficult to learn on the scale that I did in undergrad as a fulltime professional. What do you guys do to increase the depth and breadth of your skills outside of work, if anything? Online courses (Udacity, EdX, etc)? Online courses through universities for credit? Hackerspaces? Personal projects?
