Hey ladies, I'm a bit of a non-traditional student (homeschooled and then a long break btw high school and college due to running a business and health issues).

I'm looking to transfer from my current school. I'm presently an interaction design major, but I'd like to get into something more technical. I don't have the math prereqs for most engineering schools, so I'd have to apply as undeclared. I plan to spend this summer brushing up on math, but I won't have it done before the app period is over.

I was fortunate enough to get a free ride to my present institution in San Francisco, which I'm grateful for. Unfortunately I've discovered that art school is a very bad fit for me, both for cultural reasons and health issues (I find art studios much more demanding than even hardcore science classes with heavy labs). 

So I'm looking for a school that's transfer friendly (including on a financial aid level—many schools don't give transfers aid) and also disabled friendly.

Bonus points for schools in NYC, LA/S CA, FL and TX. Totally foreign-friendly too, though financial aid is often less.

USC is currently my first choice, and I've applied there and the top 4 UCs as well.

Oh, I'm also mixed white/West Asian/Mexican so I'd prefer a more diverse school and meet some of those diversity quotas. :P

Feel free to throw out some options or suggestions. :) Thanks!

Oh and edited to add that while "prestige" is nice, I'm looking more for cultural fit and a place where I can be happy and grow.

Passing along an opportunity for a two-year program with Make School. I had a call with one of the founders yesterday, and unfortunately they had few women apply. It's a new program, so my initial thought was an aversion to risk but would love any thoughts you have as to why so few women have applied. FWIW, it seems like an interesting model (8 months class, 6 months internship, 8 months --> FT eng). 

makeschool.com

Make School is a 2 year program in San Francisco for future founders and developers. Companies including LinkedIn, Lyft, Tilt, Teespring, Hipmunk, Edmodo, and a variety of smaller startups have partnered with Make School to recruit their students and help shape a relevant CS curriculum. The entire program is project based, even the theoretical components, so students build a portfolio of products as they study. Make School does not charge tuition up front, instead they take a % of salary. Their typical student has just graduated high school or completed 1-2 years of college and is looking for the best way to prepare for a career in tech.

As part of the Google Anita Borg Scholarship, we have started a project to help high school students discover computer science through an AppInventor tutorial. We are throwing workshops in Albania, Bulgaria and Spain, but the tutorial can also be followed online in 6 different languages. If you want a high school student to discover CS, please share it with them http://www.mecodeprogram.com If you are interested in helping us translate our tutorial to other languages, let us know :)

“We’ve begun to raise daughters more like sons... but few have the courage to raise our sons more like our daughters.” Maker culture, with its goal to get everyone access to the traditionally male domain of making, has focused on the first. But its success means that it further devalues the traditionally female domain of caregiving, by continuing to enforce the idea that only making things is valuable. Rather, I want to see us recognize the work of the educators, those that analyze and characterize and critique, everyone who fixes things, all the other people who do valuable work with and for others—above all, the caregivers—whose work isn’t about something you can put in a box and sell." - Gloria Steinem

Hey guys! I'm helping plan a hackathon called Codestellation at Brandeis University. It's coming up in two weeks (November 14 - 15) and we're still looking for more people to sign up! 

Codestellation is a hackathon focused on inclusivity, collaboration, and learning. Anybody can attend, and we encourage beginners and first time hackathoners to come! Our goal is to create a fun, low-stress environment where students can make new friends, learn about new tech, and hopefully build something they're really passionate about.

The hackathon is Nov. 14 - 15 in the Shapiro Science Center at Brandeis University in Waltham, MA. Unfortunately we won't be able to provide travel reimbursements, but Waltham is super easily accessible by bus and commuter rail from Boston. If you're looking for a low-key, fun opportunity to learn something new and spend time on a project you've been meaning on starting, come to Codestellation!

Hey guys! March 27-28 Brandeis University is throwing a small, friendly hackathon. There's no travel reimbursement, but anyone in the Boston area should be able to get to it easily. We're really looking to bridge the gender gap at this hackathon and get more women to come to our event - I know it seems like a lot of these events are very male-centered and 1337-hax0r-centered, which can be offputting and cause a lot of women to be nervous about going to hackathons. Definitely consider coming if you're looking for a friendly, low-key event where you can just hang out, meet new people, and make awesome things!

You can reach me directly at sofiya@codestellation.io with any questions or requests or whatever else you guys need :)

Hey everyone! For the past few months, Dan and I have been working on Redspread as part of Y Combinator's W16 batch. We just open sourced Spread, a command line tool to deploy Docker to Kubernetes in one command. Not only does it make working with Docker in production a lot simpler, it makes it easier to deploy self-hosted apps in general. You all are the most supportive community I know - would really appreciate feedback via issues/PRs and love via Github stars :) We have a lot of work to do still, but I'm still so so excited to finally get to show everyone what we've been working on!

Hey all, I've seen a lot of posts here lately that are roughly on the order of "this sexist thing happened to me," or "does this sexist thing ever happen to you?" While I 100% think this should be a safe space for those types of rants and support-seeking posts, I want to remind everyone that when gross judgey things happen, it's always an opportunity for education. Plenty of people make huge gaffes but mean well, and while sometimes people are just jerks, the most productive thing to do when you are slighted due to sex or gender is educate. Explain why what they've said or done was foolish or derogatory, and the likeliest thing is they will be embarrassed and change their behavior in the future. I know I'm preaching, but I really feel this is the surest way to turn more passive bystanders into active allies in the tech community, and I want to bring it to the forefront of our minds again.

I am working with a research team at the University of Washington improve Practice-it.  Practice-it is a free online practice tool developed for students taking the introductory programming classes at UW, but we are finding that a lot of high school computer science students also use it.  Because high school CS students tend to be more diverse than college CS students, UW is giving us diversity money to make Practice-it better for high schoolers and hopefully encourage more of them to study CS in college.

I would love any feedback you have about any of these tools, or information about any tools I don't know about!  We are eventually going to conduct a systematic survey of high school computer science teachers, but first we need to figure out what questions to ask.

Ugh. Checked my LinkedIn to find this:

It's not just random spam because I did work in molecular dynamics simulations. But like...why would you default to sir :(

http://ncase.me/polygons/

This is an awesome application of visualization and simulations to show how intuition can be wrong. Cute shapes + interactivity means that people who aren't necessarily going to read about social justice issues might at least have some of their notions challenged.

The TL;DR is that even if individuals "don't mind" living in a diverse area, if they are afraid to be in the minority and don't make an *active effort* to diversify, the overall society will become segregated.

Another phenomenon that might work well in a simulator like this is the effect explained here: http://iangent.blogspot.com/2013/10/the-petrie-multiplier-why-attack-on.html possibly withe the inclusion of the pipeline problem as well (e.g. everyone starts with some amount of self-confidence, drops by delta every time they have a biased experience, quit when no more self-confidence. They are then replaced randomly from a pipeline which is not representative, simulation continues.) My thought is that we would see diversity decrease unless there were special efforts made to help under-represented populations. Might help some people see that "reverse discrimination" doesn't actually give an *unfair* advantage to a minority population?

Since we’ve posted our private beta here on Ladies Storm Hackathons, many of you have written us asking to join. We are happy to announce that we're now accepting more users.

Software Engineers ourselves, we've built Pramp in order to help developers cope with a major recruiting challenge: how to demonstrate their full potential at job interviews. So many great software engineers miss amazing job opportunities because coding and interviewing are two different skills. 

By bringing developers practice live interviews together and providing them with the tools to do so, we allow software engineers to prepare as much as they want and whenever they want.

Pramp is completely free and provides everything you need for successful technical mock interviews: we match you automatically with a great practicing peer, send you the interview content in advance, and also provide integrated HD video chat & collaborative code editor to practice. 

To sign up go to www.pramp.com

For any questions, thoughts or feedback feel free to comment below.
Pramp is a place where software developers can practice live coding interviews as many times as they want, whenever they want. For free.

"Collaborative Fund currently has 28.6% female-founded portfolio companies.

All of the numbers, including ours, are woefully low. Among those companies, too, the majority of them (>60%) had a male co-founder, as well. Attend IDHack16!!

The 4th annual International Development Hackathon (IDHack) is a 24-hour hackathon that brings together hackers, international development enthusiasts, and NGOs from the greater Boston area to work on projects that will make an impact on international development.

All skill levels welcome!

Website: http://idhack.developersfordevelopment.org/
Hackathon Sign up: idhack16.eventbrite.com

For questions email directors.idhack@gmail.com!

Sponsors: Qualcomm, 3Red, JPMorgan, Microsoft, Google, Blockchain, Lyft

Interested in international development and/or technology?

Come to ID Hack, a 24-hour hackathon co-organized by student groups at Harvard, MIT, and Tufts that brings together hackers, technology enthusiasts, and organizations working in international development to create impact with technology.

Organizations and companies at the event include the UN World Food Programme, World Bank, Google, Qualcomm, and more.

All skill levels welcome! See event page for details.

My friends and I entered the Verizon App Challenge and are now in the running for the Fan Favorite. Our app, Vroom ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m9dn_zE3pLs) is a school based carpooling app that allows students to easily find a ride home through carpooling.

The award would give $15,000 to our school to promote STEM in classrooms and extracurriculars. A large portion of the money would be going to our robotics team(which is underfunded at the moment), so this will really help us out! Every vote counts as we're currently in 2nd place.

To vote, text "VROOM2" to the number 22333. (I promise this won't sign you up for spam or anything heart emoticon ). Thank you!

This is incredible: 

"Most people don’t have access to being creators in the app world like they are in every other part of creative endeavor. Yet this is where we’re spending most of our time. So when we asked this question about whose values are shaping our apps, what does it mean that we’re not including people who know what it is to be marginalized, who know what it is to not be the default menu option? What is the impact it has on our apps, on our culture? At the same time, we have to ask who’s benefiting from us using these apps?"

Hey folks!

The very excellent ScotlandJS is returning this year. 

More than that, they are holding a series of Diversity workshops to help broaden access to speaking opportunities. What that means is: if you are interested in speaking at a wonderful javascript conference, and you have no idea where to start, or you're not sure it's for you, there is a group of lovely supportive people meeting in a city near you who want to chat.

Check them out here, the locations are Glasgow, London, Edinburgh and Dublin. 

I attended and spoke at ScotlandJS last year, and it was a wonderful experience. I hope some of you submit a talk! If you can't make it to the workshops, but want to chat about conference/meetup talks and how to get started anyway, I'd love to help or point you to someone more appropriate!

Reading this great paper for women's studies about how we see technology as more progressive than it really often is...

tl;dr a lot of 'amazing groundbreaking' technology only really helps really privileged people in the Western world and it'd be nice to
1. see more efforts towards helping those that need it more
2. not judge how developed and progressive cultures are by how much their technology is like Western technology

"stop and rethink our basic working assumptions regarding progress and technology. [...] that progress is inevitable and that it is measured by technological change. This implies an unquestioning acceptance of technological development - since it is, by definition, progressive. But it is imperative to challenge this assumption and examine the purpose and direction of technological development. We need to be more concerned about a just distribution of its benefits."

"Progress is America's destiny, and technology is the method and the evidence. [...This] claims not only that technology assures continuous improvement in the West, but that it also allows 'the rest of the world to advance quickly to Western economic and technical standards!' Thus, a Western definition and standard of progress through technology is viewed as a universal standard"

Hey all :) I'm working on an app and would love your feedback on something relating to intersectionality (and a few other things if you're interested)

The app: http://whatprivilege.me/ (an online privilege app - note there aren't many responses right now but please do try it out to contribute your answers to the database!)

#1: There are two questions we ask that ask if people are represented in society 
- Professionals of your race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, or ability have been positively discussed or publicized within the last month.
- You commonly see people with aspects of your identity you feel strongly about (e.g. race, ethnicity, gender, sexual orientation, ability) positively portrayed in the media.

People often find these questions hard to answer because they feel very represented in certain parts of their identity but not at all in others. I was thinking of phrasing it such that people would say yes if they felt like they could see themselves in media, in however their identity feels to them. Any ideas on ways to phrase these questions? 

#2: A lot of people find the negations confusing.
Right now answering 'yes' always means (though of course it's not this black and white) that you had this kind of privilege - which is why there's the negations. 
- Do you think that's a good visual for consistency? 
- Is there another way to word the questions to get the same answers, but less confusing?
- Would having yes/no always mean the same thing kind of allow people to not think about the answer? (people could start associating one with "good" and the other with "bad" and potentially biasing the rest of their answers)

Also any other feedback is very welcome! I want to make this awesome and helpful. Thanks <3

So lately, I have been thinking about the real, constructive ways to get women interested in computer science, engineering, and related fields. I was wondering, what work (paid or volunteered) do some of you do to help younger women come into the field? (i.e. working summer camps, Girls Who Code volunteering, etc.) 

Because if we want to see more diverse hackathons then they have to be at least interested in the field or majoring in a related major in the first place. I've been working a few years on this, but I'd love to hear what others are doing to share ideas, different types of volunteering, etc. And related to hackathons, for example, it is tough to have a 35% female attendance if there's only 15% in related majors at an university.

Hey all! I would love your thoughts on this, because I'm feeling kinda scared:

So a couple of months back I visited a company and really loved the workplace - the problems they were working on, the collegiality and the people. I had a couple of conversations after with the principal engineer and we agreed to keep in touch while I spend a year abroad from September. 

Now fast forward a few weeks and I'm getting quite frequent emails from the principal engineer saying he hopes I'm well. Nothing in the content suggests anything but the frequency is starting to disturb me. I want to keep things polite and professional and am planning to give a short reply in a couple of days, but I'm wondering if he's trying to see how far he can push this. He's married, by the way. I was thinking this company would be my first choice but now am not so sure. I've even considered casually mentioning a fictitious boyfriend so he backs off! 

Help much appreciated!

Xoxo

Hi all, 

I get asked quite often what do I do at Major League Hacking and how I got involved (w/ a non-technical background). Here's an interview with Ways We Work to answer those questions: bit.ly/1Rtmv9L. 

Less about the article. Two main takeaways from being interviewed:

(1) I realized that I'm terrible at story telling. I want to build my personal brand so I look for a platform (Medium/Twitter/Facebook/personal blog/another website..etc) and use it to help me build MY brand (in this case, my brand = Li Chen).

(2) I cold emailed the founder of Ways We Work and pitched myself. No connections. No referrals. YOU ARE YOUR OWN PR. I was hesitant at first to email her (imposter syndrome?) but I'm glad I did. 

As you're looking for internships/jobs or starting an entry level, I hope you start thinking/crafting/telling your story. It's definitely a plus. 

Shared with love,

Li

Hey everyone,

I go to the Illinois Math and Science Academy (IMSA), an accelerated STEM high school. We should have a killer cs program, right? But we don't.

So right now, a group of students is working closely with school administrators to completely revamp our computer science program.

One of the problems in high school cs education is that it's not always appealing to women. Being able to rebuild the entire program, especially at this level, gives us the opportunity to inspire females to pursue these things as they go on to college.

That being said, what do you think are some good ways (activities, methods, etc) to get females engaged in a cs classroom?

Here's my lady-powered-team-storming-a-hackathon success story:

In November, I was lucky enough to work with 2 wonderful ladies (Zahra and Jackie) and one awesome guy (Jelle, who doesn't have fb) at the Al Jazeera Innovation and Research Canvas hackathon. As an aside, you should all follow that page and apply for their hackathon next year - it was a great one.

We hacked together a browser extension that semantically analyzes the news articles you read, and shows you articles about the same story that were written from different perspectives. This helps you explore the many different sides to each news story, and be more informed about all the issues surrounding newsworthy events.

We were really excited by the resulting project and the response we got (lots of chatter and 1st grand prize, "Most innovative"). Now we're gunning for the People's Choice award  - if you think our project sounds cool, we would really appreciate a vote! Voting goes until Thurs at 10:45pm EST.

We're also working to get a beta version released on the Chrome store, and would love help integrating with more news APIs. If you're interested in helping out, let me know! Open source projects ftw.

~~~Helpful voting instructions by Jackie:
1. Go to the project page at http://canvas.challengepost.com/submissions/30689-perspectives
2. Click the yellow "Vote" button.
3. Follow the instructions to create a Challengepost account (if you don't already have one). You can delete this later - it's harmless and they won't send you spam.

Thank you!

Hi everyone, I have a question that's been in my mind for a while and I sometimes think I should not think that way - so wanted to ask it here so I could hear some more opinions.

Say you meet/hear someone in your school/work place/neighbourhood/party, who you know to be going into the tech workforce and this person is extremely racist/sexist and discriminatory against others in an open, loud and frequent manner. While you've never been "directly" attacked by that person, you've seen it happening more than once and it's very inflammatory and what seems to me unstoppable (we're not talking about unconscious bias here). So I'm here worried that other people (especially these from visible minorities) will actually have to work with this (type of) people and that it could be prevented. 

So my question is: do you say something? Should you say something? Who do you say it to? Is this unfair with that person (because they may change)?

Would love any feedback!

SAGAL: You have been referred to - not by me - as the physics babe. So have you had to learn to present yourself differently than back during the many, many days when you were just in the lab or in a classroom working out problems?

RANDALL: It's actually true. You know, I had this illusion that if I kind of dressed badly that I wouldn't stand out. You know, so I actually went out of my way to not look different to the extent I could. But, you know, when you start doing public stuff, you realize, you know, you just look weird if you do that. Hello Everyone!

Brandeis University needs your assistance!

On Friday, November 20th, at 1:30 pm, students at Brandeis University held a rally on the Rabb steps, at which they spoke out about racism on campus and listed off a set of demands by concerned students. After that, they marched across campus to the president's office and have been there doing a sit-in ever since.

The students have made a list of demands, one of which encourages the school to diversify the faculty within the sciences.

It would be a great pleasure if you all could share our story via the following hashtags #fordhall2015 and #concernedstudent2015 to stand in solidarity with us.

Thank you!

Best wishes, 
Joelle

Open question for discussion: How can technical interviewers be better? What sort of things do they do that cause you to performance worse? What can they do to help you perform at your best? What do wish interviewers were told during interview training?

(I conduct interview training for tech companies and I talk a lot about how to help candidates perform at their best. Just curious if there are things that I've missed.)

I know many of you are at Grace Hopper, which is awesome. I very much support the mission of more women in tech. 

I'm often asked why I'm not speaking at Grace Hopper. I did in fact apply to speak last year. I was accepted, and ultimately declined. This is why.

Grace Hopper *charges* its speakers to attend. Yes, that's right. You get accepted to attend -- and then they make you buy a ticket. To do your own talk. I believe they offer speakers a discount, but still.

This is not normal. I've never seen a conference charge its own speakers. In fact, most conferences I see pay for speakers travel as well. But, at the very minimum, you get a free ticket (and often one for a colleague/friend too).

By charging the speakers, GHC sends a message that the speakers are not valued. It also creates issues where speakers who are cash-tight can't give their own talk.

I've seen bits of conversation here and there about this policy (finally!) and I think it'd be well worth it to start a petition about this. I don't have the time to lead this right now and I think it'd be a good opportunity for someone else anyway. I'd be the first to sign though and I'd help a bit with some social media love.

So... anyone want to start a petition?

Hi everyone! I'm having some trouble choosing a location preference for an internship and could really use some help from anyone who has interned for a tech company in New York (if you've worked for Google specifically, even better!). 

I was in Cambridge last summer and REALLY enjoyed my time there. My housing situation couldn't have been better, and I go to school nearby so my friends were able to visit often. I also made a lot of strong connections and real friendships with my coworkers, both full time and interns alike. However I think the New York office has more interesting projects. It's close to home, too, which is a positive but doesn't tip the scales really. That said I'm worried about my housing situation there (after hearing horror stories about how difficult it is to find somewhere both affordable and clean, which are really my only criteria) and the thought of starting over is less than comfortable. 

Tldr:

Cambridge: fantastic living situation, established connections and opportunity to strengthen them
NYC: more interesting project, very unsure housing situation, opportunity to make more connections???

Any advice drawing on your own experiences would be fantastic, thank you!

After a few years of coding interviews, my friends and I noticed it's always hard to find good practice buddies. There was no place to get real practice, so we built Pramp for programmers like us.

Pramp is a free peer-2-peer practice platform for coding interviews. We have 23% women on the site and we want to empower more ladies to ace their interviews.

We pair you to other programmers at your level and give you full interview questions & solutions. On each interview you and your peer interview each other on our site using video chat & collaborative code editor.

Priya Haji Fellowship -- FULL TIME 

True Ventures, a San Francisco-based early stage venture capital firm, is recruiting for its 2016-2017 Priya Haji Fellowship.
 
Designed to complement our seven-year-old True Entrepreneur Corps program, the Priya Haji Fellowship matches recent college graduates with companies in the True portfolio. This nine-month fellowship begins September 1, 2016, and will give young entrepreneurs the chance to get their foot in the door in high growth startups in the True portfolio. While this program will be open to all recent graduates, we are acutely aware of the challenges faced by women of all ages interested in breaking into the startup world and we hope and expect that at least half of our Fellows will be women. Fellows will work full-time with True portfolio companies in areas including engineering, business development, customer success, product and more. Additionally, the group will gather periodically with the True Ventures team and participate in annual True network events to develop a broader perspective on the venture capital process and the Bay Area startup ecosystem.
 
Priya Haji Fellows receive a monthly stipend of $5,000. The program’s application deadline is January 31, 2016. For more information, please visit www.trueventures.com/PHF or email PHF@trueventures.com.

Hi LSH! I need your help!

I just wrote a big long post on my blog, La Vie en Code, going through Google's Guide to Technical Development with some additional explanation for new/novice programmers. There's so much in the self-taught programming industry that is missing from the traditional 4-year university CS track, and I'm looking to close that gap by identifying what we need to become not just competent programmers -- but EXCEPTIONAL programmers.

I'd love your feedback on it, or any type of discussion at all! My goal is to break it down into bite-size, palatable pieces for folks, and make it less scary. (I have my work cut out for me :) ) If I'm missing anything, or you feel that something would be valuable to include even though I haven't gotten to learn it myself yet, please let me know.

TL;DR: We got resources. Check the group description on the right.

This group has grown a lot over the last few months (we hit the 2500 members mark this week) so this is just a reminder of what we've got available. This is normally listed in the group description, but that doesn't always get read. So this is me amplifying the resources we have available to help amplify you.

Slack channel. If you don't know what Slack is, it's basically a group chat. (learn more at slack.com) You can sign up for our Slack by referencing the post below. Use it to discuss anything you want or chat with others for help. Need to vent about an interview you're worried about or something at the office that maybe pissed you off/discouraged you/or made you uncomfortable? We gotchu. Need to help with a technical topic and need to talk through the problem with someone? We gotchu. Trying to find someone who interviewed at the same place you did or maybe already works there? We gotchu too. Want to share something cool you helped build or write or organize? We so gotchu. Possibilities so endless. 

Medium Collection. (https://medium.com/ladies-storm-hackathons) Don't wait for someone else to write your story. Submit technical blog posts, tech opinion pieces, post-mortems from hackathon--- whatever you want. Read what other women are writing. Help amplify them on social media. Recommend each other's stories.

Twitter: @TheLSHStorm. Tweet us when you want us to share something you did. Follow us to hear what other women are doing. We tweet resources for women in tech (scholarships for schools and conferences) and general Women in Tech interest. We love amplifying members, so shoot us an @. 

GitHub: (https://github.com/Ladies-Storm-Hackathons) We collect resources to help you in classes and have bounced around a few other projects. Think we're missing something? Submit a PR. We collectively own this, and if you found a resource helpful, chances are someone else will too.

LSH Jobs and Internships: (https://www.facebook.com/groups/LSHJobs/) Subgroup for job-specific stuff. 

Meetups: Going to a hackathon or conference? See if there's an LSH meetup scheduled. If not, gauge interest and start the event yourself. 

I'm probably forgetting something, so if any LSHers think of anything, add it here.

This is a thought I've mulled over for a while, but I decided to post this as I think it might be a interesting discussion topic and I'd like to hear your views....

Does anyone else ever feel a bit guilty at the thought of applying for diversity scholarships to conferences/tech events?

I'm sure like many of you who are also students, I don't exactly have money flowing out of my ears and these things often cost of £200+ ($300+~) for one-day conferences. But from the few opportunities I've had to attend such things, I've found them incredibly valuable.

At the same time, I've worked hard to secure and work my ass off at paid internships to be able to support the life I am living. So in theory, the money is in my bank account, so I feel that someone who genuinely doesn't have the money should receive a scholarship instead.

At the same time, I definitely would not feel justified paying that amount at the moment and would not go to the event at all in that case, which defeats the point of the scholarship existing in the first place.

Any thoughts?

Hi! This is the first group of female coders I've been in. I'd be interested in your views on something I thought of after reading the previously posted article. In it, the writer tells of male colleagues who mock women as being "only" good for front-end/design work, and relates how she and her female colleagues stand up to it.

I've coded primarily in C/++ for several years now and really enjoy making stuff, but I've also been an artist/designer and interested in writing/psychology for over a decade. Hence I find myself also drawn to UX design and PMish roles at hackathons etc. However, I've always found it hard to deal with the deep shame I feel whenever I take on any role that isn't "developer". I feel I'm a disappointment to all women in tech, including the writer of that article, by playing precisely into the stereotypes that hurt us as a whole: that we can't code, that all we are good for is flowery fluffy design and humanities stuff. I feel guilty that I, an ardent proponent of gender/racial/sexual-orientation equality in tech, have the audacity to *choose* to step away from coding into less technical positions - to *willingly* give our critics more ammunition. I feel that I lose what little legitimacy I have to comment on issues facing women in tech - even if such issues are faced also by non-developers.

I don't know if this is just in my head - but I sometimes wonder if even many of my fellow women might no longer take me seriously once I take off the engineer hat. I often feel like a fraud even among women, a pretender with no right to be as vocal as I am about marginalization, since I deserve the stereotypes - after all, I am a walking collection of them. I feel a need to prove myself to not only men, but also to a feminist discourse that seems to tell me women in tech are equal and valued - but only if they are engineers.

Anyone felt the same way? Anyone disagrees? Do I just have a bad case of engineer worship? Have your own anecdotes? I'd love to hear your thoughts. I'm excited to finally meet a large community of women who love tech and look forward to your responses.

[s/woman/!(cis&male) . written on a phone, please excuse typos]

Hi everyone, 

We're in the process of designing a system for creating recommendation websites from scratch using *only* a list of items--no coding required. The link for the website is kibitz.csail.mit.edu. If you would like to create a recommendation website, simply click on the link and follow the instructions to create a recommendation website. 

However, we need some help determining whether the recommendation algorithms give reasonable recommendations.

We've made two recommenders:

Board Games: http://kibitz.csail.mit.edu/amyxzhang/board_games/
Books: http://kibitz.csail.mit.edu/q2liu/books_recommender/

Using our system. We would like to hear your opinions on whether the recommendations are good. Simply go to the website and rate some items. After you rate the items, you should see some recommendations under "My Recommendations." The website works on Firefox, Chrome, and IE (there is currently a bug in Safari).

If you have ~10 minutes, please try either one or both of the recommenders above and fill out the following survey:

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1b-ztSYUntr1Upnut6au2fc-RgKIVchp-_CBLr7AxX3Y/viewform?usp=send_form

You will also be entered in a drawing for one of 3 $20 Amazon gift cards if you fill out the survey. 

We really appreciate any suggestions, advice, or bug reports. Feel free to comment here or sent an email to team-mit-recs@mit.edu.
If interested, email on this address: sysuchak@syr.edu

Quick tip for your job-searches: If you are using a cloud method of sharing your resume with potential employers, make sure it is definitely accessible to people you send it to!

I have been receiving resumes over the past couple of weeks and a lot of people are trying to attach cloud-based documents. It's fine if it's done right, but there have been a lot of people with whom I had issues. I have received resumes linked from several different sites that wanted me to create an account in order to view their resume.  And then there's Google Drive, in which case they "attach" the file but when I click it, I am told I need to request permission from the file's owner.  Again, hoops to jump through - not good!  So make sure that if you're sending your resume out in a less common format, you know exactly what your potential employer will see, and what they will need to do to see it!

Hey y'all! HackTX registration starts TOMORROW!! This year, HackTX will be on Sept. 26th-27th. HackTX is a student-run, 24 hour long hackathon. It's a great place to improve and learn skills, and meet amazing people - all while building awesome, techy stuff. We really encourage anyone who is interested to sign-up, even if you are a complete hackathon beginner. One of our main goals is to encourage a diverse set of people to come (beginners, underrepresented groups, non CS/CE majors, etc.) to attend. There will be mentors and plenty of other students to help you out! There will be food and lots of fun stuff to do! Come join in on an awesome weekend of hacking! You can sign-up and get more details @ http://hacktx.com. We would love to see a bunch of y'all there! <3 The HackTX Team

Not sure if this has been discussed before, but how do you guys feel about the term “guys” as a gender-neutral term to address a group of people? I actually don't mind it-- I feel a bit uncomfortable every time my scrum master says “Good morning guys, and girl” *looks at me and smiles*.

It’s a minor detail, I know it was done in good intent (to be inclusive, esp because I’m in a team of 10+ men), and I appreciate the gesture, but I’d actually prefer “guys” over being singled out. Thoughts?

Hey ladies- I hope nobody minds me posting this here since it's a bit recruity (if this violates the group rules or something I'll happily take it down), but I'm not a recruiter - I'm just another technical woman who's very excited to announce that I get to have my own intern next summer... which means I'm hiring! And I thought some of you might be interested in a position like this, so:

The deets-
I work for Amplify Education, where I'm the tech lead on
a fun product called Quests for the Core
(www.amplify.com/curriculum/quests-for-the-core) - an interactive
digital ELA (English Language Arts) experience for elementary and middle school students. I'm especially looking to fill an intern spot on my own team
for this summer (the particular job posting is here: http://ch.tbe.taleo.net/CH14/ats/careers/requisition.jsp?org=WIRELESSGENERATION&cws=1&rid=3749); we're looking for someone with a good command of front-end development - jQuery and AngularJS skills are preferable - but Amplify as a whole is huge and has a variety of fun projects and openings for full-time and internship positions that use different technologies (including Unity3D, Grails, Java, and Python, to name a few).

Amplify is a really fun place to work with a lot of people who are passionate about education and creating fun experiences for our students. We do a lot of hands-on playtesting with real students to make sure our apps really work and are the best they can be.

For more information, check out our jobs page http://www.amplify.com/careers or get in touch with me at nbieber@amplify.com - I'd be happy to chat with you more about the company or try put you in touch directly with a team that might be
interested in your particular skillset.

Hi everyone! I'm organizing a new hackathon in Michigan called MythicApps. Currently, only 30% of our applicants are female. This is... decent, but we definitely definitely definitely want more girls to come out.

This is the first big hackathon that Lansing will see and since it's literally in the capital of Michigan, I really want there to be a big ladies presence. MythicApps is part of the Capital Tech Initiative and if we can get a lot of women at the event, we'll not only be making a statement about Lansing's quickly-growing tech scene, but also about women's interest in the tech scene! 

Thank you to LSH for existing. It's really inspiring to girls like me who want to build and inspire other girls. Because I've been successful and supported by a great community of women in tech, my little sister (10th grade) is taking all the CS courses she can in high school and learning HTML/CSS/JS from General Assembly. She's also coming to MythicApps to learn more this September. 

Anyways, you all rock. <3 Thanks.

https://www.mythicapps.io

Have any of you heard of the International Women's Hackathon yet?  The event is sponsored by Microsoft Research, and is essentially an umbrella term for a series of hackathons for women that will be hosted by many universities around the world on the same weekend (April 25-27, 2014).  The website for the event (see below) provides a really clear explanation of the goals of the event -- I encourage you to check it out, and if possible, plan one at your own college or university.  If you have any questions, please shoot them my way -- I was on the planning committee for the overarching Microsoft event, and I am currently planning one of these hackathons at RIT.

I don't usually speak up about issues like this, but today I saw something that really bothered me. 

It's a post shared by a popular programming Google+ page. I guess I've never seen such blatant misogyny. It would be one thing if there was a third panel with a dude on it talking about a decision, then at least the message would be "ooh I'm a programmer and I'm better than you because of technical decisions I have to make", but that's clearly not the message. It's just kind of sad that this is posted on a popular page and generally well received. I know if I had seen pictures like this when I was younger, I'd be extremely discouraged from studying computer science if I thought this is the impression other students would have of me. 

I guess it's just the most bothersome that this post actually has more +1's than many of the others on the page, and only one of the comments addresses that it's insulting.

https://plus.google.com/u/0/+KelseyHrubes/posts/jZ9u7Mn66Lt?pid=6070739000416701586&oid=107749084227309383348

DiscoTech (Discovering Technology) is an event where you can come and learn about technology at the MIT Media lab! I especially like this bc they're trying to implement the following philosophy:

"Note to technical folk: We are all used to going to events designed for us as activists, as hackers, as designers. We get great things done when we're around people we share a language with, and who "get it." But we also need to talk to users who come from different backgrounds. It is important to spend time with people who are unlike you, to be sure the futures we build are more accessible. We all need specific things our usual crowd can't provide - and similarly, you provide skills others don't have at their disposal."
My SO helped ship this today so I had to share. This is really awesome! #shiplove

Great read I found on Hacker News:
"Why does anyone, anywhere, think this will work? Start with a young woman who's already formed her identity. Dump her in a situation that operates on different social scripts than she's accustomed to, full of people talking about a subject she doesn't yet understand. Then tell her the community is hostile toward women and therefore doesn't have enough of them, all while showing her off like a prize poodle so you can feel good about recruiting a female."

Here's a hackathon focused on helping people, not just impressing them! 

Want to use technology to change health care? Then you do not want to miss HackDC 2015 (www.HackDC.com). In this 36-hour in-person hackathon in the Washington, DC Metro area on Sept 25-27, several hundred university students (along with a few corporate teams) will focus their creativity and design/coding skills on building mobile apps for post-traumatic stress disorder / traumatic brain injury (PTSD/TBI), with a bit of help from clinicians, veterans, and veterans' families and friends. There will be free food, prizes, API workshops, and fun activities. Make new friends, meet technology companies, sponsors, and federal healthcare leaders, and create an awesome mobile app. Be sure to join us in a great cause! Capacity is limited, and you must be over 18. For more information, please go to HackDC

TL;DR: Vote for me here: bit.do/voteTina (my full name is Christina Li, I'm the one with the greenish hair) for Hello World, my computer science day camp for middle school girls!

Hey everyone! <3 As some of you may know, I organized and hosted a computer science day camp for 30 middle school girls during spring break a few weeks ago, called Hello World. With a group of volunteers, I taught game design (Scratch), app development (MIT AppInventor), robotics (Finch), and web development (HTML/CSS). On the last day, we traveled to Ann Arbor (Michigan) to visit the engineering campus of the University of Michigan and Google Ann Arbor. 

Anyways, I submitted this initiative in Microsoft's Youthspark Challenge for Change competition, and somehow, I'm one of the 15 finalists for the 13-17 age group out of thousands of other applicants! To go the next round, it's all voting-based, and it literally just takes a minute to vote. Just go bit.do/voteTina, click my face, and type in your email. You can vote once every day from May 7, 2015-May 14, 2015, and it would mean the world to me if you all can vote for me! If you want a daily reminder to vote (like I said, it literally takes less than a minute), you can subscribe here: http://eepurl.com/bmijX9.  The prize is a $2500 grant (among other things) for the program, which I'd love to use to host another field trip to a tech office nearby. You can get more information about my program on tina98.github.io/HelloWorld/, or just read the description/watch my video on bit.do/voteTina. 

Thank you so much for everything ❤

I am a international graduate student studying Computer Science at San Jose State University, CA. I am participating in the Climate Ride California 2015. I am trying to raise funds for our non profit, the Green Ninja Project, which advocate climate change education.

I want to inspire women in STEM fields to take up more challenges, in every sphere of their life. I want to set an example of success. I want to people to approach adversity with a 'can do' attitude. Please support me. Thank you.

Wellesley College and Simmons College are collaborating to hold a hackathon on the weekend of April 17th - April 19th! It will be hosted on Wellesley's campus and we would love for anyone interested in hacking to join us!
Why should you come to the Wellesley Simmons Hackathon? 
To promote women in computer science and engineering 
To network with professionals, companies, and students from other colleges who genuinely share your interest in programming 
To build something really, really cool. This year’s theme is completely open, so you are free to play around with any idea that interests you or would be useful to you.
If you’d like to sign up, please do so here: http://ws-hack-with.me/!
Any questions? Email us at csclub@wellesley.edu or tweet at @ws_hackathon.
Please also make sure to visit our website (http://ws-hack-with.me/) and check out this cool article (http://geekfeminism.org/2015/02/04/learning-how-to-hack-in-a-bros-world-a-womens-college-student-perspective/) written by our hackathon coordinators!

[JOB]: UX Designers, Developers, and Interns!

At the new ECMC Innovation Lab, we build tech (such as collegeabacus.org) that changes how millions of people manage - and clear - their student debt. Our ambitions extend far beyond basic service delivery; we are looking for new ways to help students succeed, and move on to bigger and better things.

We are interviewing NEXT WEEK and hiring IMMEDIATELY for:
-Junior UX Designers
-Junior Developers (Job Application will be live on Monday 3/30!)
-Part-time and Full-time Interns

Perks of the Lab:
-Beautiful casual office in downtown Washington, D.C.
-Small, vibrant, and diverse team
-Weekly “Show and Tell” to celebrate what we’ve finished every week
-Great healthcare, dental, vision and 401k benefits
-Among the many exciting and unusual aspects of the Lab is that we are now a team of 80% women.

Interested in joining us? Get your application in! (Developer application will open Monday 3/30)

PAID INTERNSHIP OPPORTUNITY: ECMC's Innovation Lab is hiring interns for the current semester and for the summer! If you are looking for opportunities in Washington, DC, this paid internship will be a hands-on experience in the world of an educational tech office - our primary "product" is College Abacus, a tool that helps students (mostly high school seniors) make informed financial decisions about their prospective college! Interns of diverse backgrounds and college majors are welcome to apply, and will work with every member of our team. Please find more information here: https://www1.apply2jobs.com/ECMC/ProfExt/index.cfm?fuseaction=mExternal.showJob&RID=150&CurrentPage=1 and please message me or comment below with any questions you may have! Hello everyone! 

So being both a women and a person of color in or interested in the tech industry is a unique challenge that some of us face. These intersecting systems of oppression pose an experience that needs to be discussed in a forum separate of the ~12,000+ strong Hackathon Hackers group and even the Ladies Storm Hackathon group. With this being said, I present HH: Women of Color. This group exists as a safe place for women of color in the hackathon scene and in the tech industry at large.

So as interview season gets intense, my friends' attitudes towards women / the recruiting process become more apparent.

I wanted to reach out to LSH about a cross-campus initiative. Data Ventures (dataventures.org) is an intercollegiate network that launched last year and we're trying to reach out to as many campuses as possible. If your school already has some sort of an undergraduate data group (or if doesn't yet), we'd love to have your campus (or help your campus) join as a division/chapter in the Data Ventures group. 

It would be awesome to see as many girls (and guys too) taking leading roles in dissolving the data disconnect in tech, biotech, finance, etc. If you have any questions or if you're interested in joining, feel free to reach out to me at smir@college.harvard.edu. 

Best, 
Amy

Hi everyone! Pasadena City College Computer Science Club is hosting She++.  She++ is an event designed to expose and encourage women to pursue a STEM degree, our main focus being Computer Science, as well as highlighting female role models in Computer Science.

We invite you to join us tomorrow at She++ for an inspiring conference at The Forum (UU building) with speakers and panelists from the technology industry, raffle, and free food! Nov 21, 2014 from 5-8 pm.

She++ would also like everyone to know that we will have American Sign Language Interpreters at the event! We are excited to have them with us and hope to see you there!

The Computer Science Club of Pasadena City College (PCC) is hosting “She++” It will be held on PCC campus at The Forum. The focus of this event is to encourage women to pursue Science Technology Engineering and Math (STEM) and Computer Science in particular. 

We will have a panel of female guest speakers to share their work and experience in technology. Many professional women who work in the Computer Science (and related field) have also volunteered to be mentors at She++.

The first half of the event will be presentations from guest speakers and a guest panel. The second half of the event will be a time for attendees and mentors to socialize and network (+ free food)! 

We will also have raffles throughout the event. Don't miss out! RSVP to let us know if you will be attending! 

We hope that you will join us for this very exciting event. Updates will be put up on this event page. 

If you have any questions or concerns, please email us at:
pccsheplusplus@gmail.com

Our website: www.sheplusplus.info
For more information: www.sheplusplus.info
Follow us on instagram to see She++ in the making @pccsheplusplus

Hello! I'm a CS and Sociology sophomore, and I was wondering if any of you wonderful people could help me out with something.

I'm taking a Sociology class called Gender & Work right now, and we have a large research project in which we have to formulate our own research topic and interview real subjects.

I chose to research the obstacles women face in the tech industry (whether internal or external, and whether these obstacles occurred when they were choosing to study CS, when they were trying to enter the workplace, or in the workplace itself).

I don't have any connections to reach out to, so I was hoping you guys could help me. I'm looking for women employed in technical jobs in tech start-ups. Interviews would be roughly 45 minutes (over Skype) and would take place sometime this month.

Please message or comment if you think you or someone you know could help me out in any way! 

Thank you so much!!!

hey ladies (and gents)! If you're considering pursuing a career in business/science/technology, or even marrying someone who is considering that, I strongly encourage you guys to pick up Lean In, the memoir/advice book by Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg. It's packed with personal anecdotes and advice for being a strong woman in the workforce and at home. It's a super quick read, and I'd love to have a discussion about it after with anyone who's read it! Tips on negotiation, family planning, partnership, etc, with TONS of personal experience stories from this awesome role model who has worked at Google and Facebook. in short: read this book!

Alright, so I just finished a discussion with a mod of my school's hackathon facebook group and it made me think about something:

Are the women in the tech industry solely responsible in educating the men about how it feels to be a woman in the field, or should the men be held somewhat responsible in educating themselves on the subject?

Obviously, there was a time when it wasn't spoken about as much, but I feel like everyone is now aware that this is an issue (whether they agree it's an issue or not, which is for another discussion I think).

tl;dr I'm sick of being blamed for other people's ignorance.

http://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/06/magazine/why-are-there-still-so-few-women-in-science.html?_r=0

An interesting read, if you haven't read it already!  It's not about computer science specifically, but it brings up some interesting points and perspectives.

Is anyone in this group based in the Atlanta area? We just opened up pre-registration for PilotAtlanta, our high school focused event at Georgia Tech. If you know any girls/beginners we'd love it if you could help spread the word. http://atlanta.gopilot.org

If you haven't heard of Pilot (www.gopilot.org), we host hands on learning events for high school students to teach them how to build real apps and websites. We're mainly focused on education (although there is a competitive aspect), so we really try to encourage beginners to participate, and one of our main focuses is having a balanced gender ratio (the other is reaching out to low income students who often don't have access to tech resources).

This is a pretty shameless ask but we'd love to get your helping to spread the word (ie over twitter, facebook, etc [or even organizing an event at your school!]). The reason I think this would be helpful is because your friends who are still in high school will see the message about getting involved in tech coming from a respected role model and feel more comfortable in attending. The other reason is that we're also trying to have a balanced mentor and judge gender ratio, so that attendees meet women they can look up to and keep in touch with, and you all have great networks of women who might be excited about getting involved. Hopefully this is pretty inline with the mission of the group and a cause that you all are passionate about. If you do tweet about it please avoid the word "hackathon" though, since we've noticed it scares a lot of beginners away.

Would be happy to discuss more in the comments. Let me know what you all think!

Hi! I'm curious if you all ever encountered times when you're interviewing with companies for internships/jobs and then you get the position, but then you also know a number of guys who interviewed for the same thing and didn't. Is there a lot of negativity around that for you? I use to think there wasn't, but last year a friend told me about how someone did talk about how I got an internship offer just because I am a girl. How do you deal with that? And how do you internally deal with the fact that sometimes a guy (whose skills you really think are better than yours) doesn't get a position you did?
I felt like I should share this here-
Thoughts?
